text:
I made this last night and it was delicious.  Used a prior reviewer's suggestion and made it in a round 2-qt casserole dish instead of a 9x13-inch pan, to avoid having a dry casserole (other than that I followed the recipe exactly).  Like previous reviewers have commented, it was just a tad on the dry side.  Wasn't so dry that my fiance and I didn't enjoy eating it (it was really tasty!), but could use about half a can more soup.  I used red onions which made for a colorful dish.  I will definitely be making this again - it's a keeper - but next time I'm going to add 1/2 can more soup to it.

text:
Overall the receipe is very good. As indicated by others, it was dry. Considering using a whole bag of noodles, I did add another can of soup and 1/2 cup of milk. Next time I make this, I think I will add sour cream in addition to the extra can of soup and milk, the mixture really needs to be pretty soupy when baked, since the noodles soak up so much of the liquid. Where did the cayenne pepper substitute come from, I didn't see it in the receipe, although it would be a good addition. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Very Good!  I usually just "wing it" when it comes to making tuna casserole, but there is a first time for everything, and I actually followed a recipe this time!  As other reviewers stated, I too added some milk to make it more creamy.  I then added about a 1/4 cup of miracle whip as well for a little zip, then I did my usual doctoring with onion and garlic powders.  Instead of using potatoe chips on top I used crushed crackers that I pulsed a few times in the food processor with some melted garlic butter.  The end reult was a very yummy tuna casserole.

text:
I ENJOYED THIS TUNA CASSEROLE. I PREPARED IT FOR MY MOTHER AND I AND IT WAS ENOUGH FOR AT LEAST 6 PEOPLE. AFTER READING THE REVIEWS ABOUT THE CASSEROLE BEING DRY AND BLAND, I MADE SOME ADJUSTMENTS. I USED A FAMILY SIZE CAN CREAM OF MUSHROOM SOUP, I PUT A LITTLE EXTRA SALT IN THE BOILING WATER THAT I COOKED THE NOODLES. I MELTED 1.5 STICKS OF BUTTER IN A SAUCEPAN AND SAUTED MY ONIONS BECAUSE I DID NOT THINK 20 MINUTES WOULD GET THEM AS TENDER AS I PREFER. OF COURSE, I ADDED THAT BUTTER TO THE MAKING OF THE CASSEROLE AS WELL. I INCREASED THE AMOUNT OF ONION CALLED FOR IN THE RECIPE TO HALF OF A LARGE ONION. I USED SHARP CHEDDAR CHEESE AS WELL FOR ADDED FLAVOR. I INCORPORATED ALL THE CHEESE INTO THE CASSEROLE AND JUST USED CRUSHED POTATO CHIPS ON TOP. I DID NOT DRAIN THE TUNA, I USED THE JUICE AS WELL TO HELP WITH THE BLAND TASTE THAT WAS MENTIONED IN SEVERAL REVIEWS. I REDUCED THE OVEN TEMP TO 350 DEGREES AS WELL TO KEEP THE CASSEROLE FROM DRYING OUT AS MUCH. THE RESULT WAS EXCELENT!!!

text:
I'm not a big fan of Tuna casserole but I gave this one a try, with a few modifications it came out a 5 star recipe.  My father in law told my mother in law to step aside and let me cook it from now on.  He told everyone it's the best F'n Tuna casserole he's ever had.... I guess that about sums it up : )  This is what i changed, I seasoned the mixture with johnnys, I did NOT add mushrooms, I used one can of cream of mushroom and one can of cream of celery, i sauteed the onions in a little bit of butter and also some celery, I added some canned corn in addition to the peas and more cheese to the mixture than it calls for.  Best I have ever had.

text:
I am not a huge fan of tuna casserole. It is always so boring, but this recipe is a great start. With a few modifications, it came it fantastic! I used 8oz of noodles instead of 12, which helped keep the dish from drying out in the oven. My family really likes onion, so I used about half of a sweet yellow, roughly chopped. I also added 1/2c sour cream and 1/4 milk to the mix. I didn't have any chips so I just used cheese as a topping, but french fried onions would be great on top. Baked in a 2qt round casserole dish for about 25 minutes at 350. You don't have to bake at such a high temperature since everything is already cooked.  You only need to thaw the peas and warm the dish. With these alterations, the casserole came out moist and delicious. My husband ate about half of it in one sitting and it makes great leftovers too! We will be having this again!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I am giving this recipe 4 stars because, while it was delicious, I had to make the suggested changes to make it work. I took advice from varying reviews, and added a little macaroni and cheese know-how, and ended up with a great casserole! There wasn't a dry noodle in the house. Here's what I did:  - Chopped up about 2/3 of a red onion and sauteed in the pan. When onions were nearly done cooking, I added about 6 sliced Baby Bella mushrooms and sauteed for a few minutes. - Meanwhile, I poured 2 cans of cream of mushroom soup in a pan. Filled each can with milk and added that as well. I brought the mixture to a boil, shut off the heat, and added about 2 1/2 to 3 cups of shredded cheese (extra to compensate for the milk). I stirred the cheese in until a cheese sauce was formed, adding salt and pepper along the way. - I then mixed the cheese sauce into the noodles, along with the tuna, onions, mushrooms and frozen veggies. Once everything was coated, I covered in flavored bread crumbs and baked. - The end result.... A+!!!!

This recipe is a good. It is fast and easy to fix. It might be a little bland and it does taste very similar to a Tuna Helper meal but has the homemade appeal instead. I used crushed corn flake cereal dredged in butter for the top since I had no potato chips on hand and it worked okay but I would definitely try the chips if I were to make it again. All in all, this is a good recipe with simple ingredients right out of the pantry. It is a recipe that will turn out just  average.

text:
I always feel bad altering a recipe... I mean following it is what makes it a recipe! I was having a hankering for tuna casserole and needed a base recipe. This worked perfect, and I loved the suggestions everyone else had too. To make this "my family" friendly, I omitted the mushrooms, onions and peas (lol) and instead used 2 cups of frozen chopped broccoli. I also put in a cup of sour cream, cayenne pepper, garlic salt and used sharp white cheddar cheese. For the top I skipped the cheese and just used crushed croutons and it was so good!! I highly recommend this recipe, either as written or doctored up. Its a really simple, delicious one!

country:
None
text:
I made this for dinner last night and it was excellent. I read the reviews first and made the following changes: 1. sauteed the onion with a little minced garlic before adding, 2. used mixed veggies instead of peas (family preference), 3. baked in a round 2 qt casserole instead of a 9x13 dish, 4. whisked the 2 cans of soup with one can of milk before adding and seasoned the soup with salt and pepper, 5. mixed most of the cheese in and sprinkled just a little on top, 6. topped with crushed whole grain Ritz instead of potato chips (family preference), 7. used whole grain egg noodles (family preference), 8. baked at 375 for 15 minutes covered, then 425 for 10 minutes uncovered.  It was moist, creamy, and delicious.  It may have needed a little more veggies and tuna, but that's personal preference.

Display Name:
Peachy

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After clicking through different tuna casserole versions and reviews, I picked this one, and I've made it numerous times - putting a different spin each time based on what's in the fridge/pantry. ALWAYS turns out FABULOUS. I think that the real beauty of this recipe is it's openness to interpretation. (Say you're in the middle of a snowstorm, like we are right now, and you have the main ingredients and some others...) Tonight I had no egg noodles (used penne), no peas (used steamed broccoli florets) and happened to have on hand some fresh basil, chicken broth and cooking sherry, so I threw those in with the 2 cans condensed soup. I added Parmesan cheese and lemon juice and zest to the sauce. It came out less like a casserole in density, since it didn't stick tight together, but HOLY COW was it DELISH!!!! Definitely this version is going in the permanent rotation! THANKS for the great recipe! One other tip: I make the whole thing in one pot - saute the onion, carrot, celery and mushroom in a dutch oven on the stove top. Stir in the frozen peas (or brocc or whatever green veggie you prefer - asparagus would be yummy too!), stir in all the other ingredients and pop the whole thing in the oven with the lid on for the first 20 mins, off for 10. 

You can fit the volume of added healthy veggies and tuna if you're using the dutch oven rather than the 13x9 pan. Makes AWESOME leftovers for DAYS.

This is my second time making it. The first time, I gave it 3 stars because it was bland and dry. The second time, I tweaked it.  MUCH better.

First I added a clove of garlic, an extra can of soup AND some sour cream.   I also added some dill weed. Dill makes tuna and salmon taste SO much better. I have no idea why.   I also used green beans instead of peas because I hate peas.

text:
This was a better than average tuna casserole, but is definitely not the best, mainly because it is so incredibly bland.  I halved the recipe since hubby doesn't eat tuna.  I knew going in that I would need more spice so I added 1 tsp. of garlic powder, 1 tsp. of coarsely ground black pepper and a 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper.  Even with those additions and all of the salt in the soup, cheese and potato chips, I still had to add extra salt and pepper upon serving.  I also didn't think there were enough peas.  Next time I make this, I intend to double the peas, add 1.5 tsp. of garlic salt, more pepper, the cayenne pepper and some red pepper flakes.  I also think it would work well to makes this with shredded chicken for the fish haters.  Good base recipe - it just needs more seasoning to be really good.

text:
this is a great old recipe that has been in my family for years, alot of other reviewers stated that it came out very dry, add about a cup of milk, or until the consistency looks right and that solves the problem. and another thing is, in order to avoid "hard cheese' on top, put the cheese on top first, then the potato chips, then the chips crisp and the cheese doesnt get too dried out.

I made this for a quick Sunday dinner. I thought the cheese was going to be too much but it blended perfectly into the casserole, and went perfectly with the crunchy potato chip topping. The only change I made was adding a quarter cup of sour cream I had sitting in the refrigerator that I wanted to use up. This is a moist and tasty recipe for anyone that loves tuna casserole. I put it in a 8x12 disposable aluminum and it baked up beautifully.

text:
I made the following changes: I sauteed the onion and some celery in garlic infused olive oil, added the mushrooms without draining them, topped it with Italian bread crumbs, added 3/4 of a soup can of milk and added fresh ground pepper. I also cooked it at 350 for 25 minutes instead of the higher temp.

It came out very moist and was very good. Next time I will try to add sour cream instead of milk, garlic and some herbs. This was very easy to make and one of the best tuna casseroles I've ever had.

text:
This is a great recipe for tuna casserole and I saved it to my favorites! I made a few changes - first sautéed onions, celery, fresh mushrooms, and garlic. Thanks to the reviews, I lowered the temp to 375 and added about 1/4 cup of milk. Mine did not come out dry at all. It was delicious! I think that 425 temp is the culprit in the dry casseroles. Also, I did not use potato chips  - I realize that’s one of the ingredients that makes this recipe unique. I just didn’t have any so I used saltine crackers instead. However, next time I will make sure I have the potato chips!

text:
This was quite tasty. I took some other reviewers' advice and added some milk to make it a little more liquidy. Also added some salt, pepper and garlic salt; didn't use any extra mushrooms as my husband doesn't like them. Substituted about 1/2 a sleeve of crushed up Ritz crackers for the topping in lieu of the potato chips. If my 4 year old wasn't so averse to anything even remotely spicy, I would have added a little cayenne as another reviewer suggested. Otherwise, my only real recommendation would be to lower the temp and cook longer...20 minutes is not enough to get the insides warm but at that temp, I believe the topping would burn if left on too much longer. So next time I'll try 350 for 30-40 minutes instead.

text:
This recipe was excellent! I did have to improvise a bit. I didnt have any cream of anything so I used mayo, milk and mustard and added a bit of cranberry sauce for a sweetener. No egg noodles on hand so I used ramen noodles (4 packages fed my entire family). I substituted the tuna with canned anchovies and black olives that made it taste great. I added creamed corn just to make it juicier and some leftover ham salad that I had in the fridge. The entire family was presently surprised and they are begging me to make it again. I may add some mashed potatoes next time to give it some texture and more flavor. Thanks so much for the recipe!! It was a hit all around!

city:

country:
None
text:
Very delicious casserole.  Here's a tip-- use a pot instead of any size bowl and a cup of sour cream.  I used the biggest bowl I have in the house and it was barely enough to mix together.  I sauteed onions and garlic and mixed that in with a can of cream of chicken and a can of cream of mushroom (woulda went mushroom all the way but that's all I had on hand.)  After reading some reviews I heard it got a bit dry in the oven so I added a cup of sour cream-- boy, am I glad I did!  Perfect consistency still after several reheats, even microwaved.  For the topping, I used Ritz Crackers in the food processor with a bit of butter and some Parmesan.  It was better the next day!!!

text:
this was the best tuna casserole i have ever eaten let alone made.  i made the substitutions which were suggested and a couple of my own.  since i am overseas, i had to make my own condensed cream of mushroom soup which i found online. made a triple batch of cream of mushroom soup using 2 big cans of mushrooms.  substitututed 2 med roasted red peppers and .5 canned corn for peas. added 2/3 c. sour cream,  spiral noodles instead of egg noodles, colby jack, cayenne, crushed garlic, salt, pepper, and extra whole milk.  my husband who is "not a tuna guy" called it "fanastic" and the whole dish was scraped clean.  by the way, this was just the right amount for a hungry family of 5 adults and 1 preteen.

text:
I made a lower fat version of this recipe and was pleased with the result.  I used whole wheat, no yolk egg noodles, 98% fat free condensed cream of mushroom soup,and  reduced fat shredded cheddar cheese.  I mixed all of the cheese into the mixture prior to baking, along with about 10 oz. of water to prevent dryness.  I used panko bread crumbs as a topping.  It came out really well, and I feel alot less guilty about indulging in tuna casserole!

text:
This is a great dish when altered to suit your own taste. I'm giving it 4 stars since I made changes others suggested to keep it from being too dry.  I added an additional 1/2 cup of cheese and 1cup of sour cream. I substituted red peppers for the mushrooms since it already had mushroom soup. The red bell pepper looked nice with the peas. I used a 12 oz. pkg of frozen peas because that's the size I had on hand. I increased the onion and sautéed it in olive oil with the peppers before adding it to the mixture.  I also added garlic and dill because we like spicy food. Then I topped it with buttery cracker crumbs and cooked half of it for 20 minutes at 350. I froze the other half for dinner another.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A good recipe which we felt needed a few alterations...
1) sauté the onions with a tsp of kosher salt, 2 tsp of fresh cracked pepper and tbsp of olive oil.  Once the onions are getting soft, add the mushrooms and cook until they start to soften.  
2) add 2 cloves of fresh chopped garlic to the onions and mushrooms.  cook for 1-2 minutes until they become fragrant. 
3) OPTIONAL: Add 1/4 cup of vodka to deglaze the pot.  Be careful if working with open flames.  I cook the vodka, onions and garlic for about another 1-2 minutes.  
4) Add 1 tsp of dried parsley
5) Add 1/2 cup of sour cream for added creaminess 
6) Optional: use cayenne pepper to season... a little goes a long way.  Be careful not to over season
8) Follow the rest of the recipe according to JAICARDs instructions.

text:
I should have followed this as written.  Because of the comments about it being too dry, I did add some sour cream and milk -- and I thought it turned out too creamy.  I added a can of pimentos, which added to the flavor and color.  To keep this easy clean up, I sauteed the onion in the same pot I cooked the noodles in while the noodles were draining in the colander, then mixed everything else in and put it in the oven.  We don't like toppings on our casserole, so just used the extra cheese on top with a little paprika.  Next time I'll leave out the sour cream and just add a small amount of milk.  I think sour cream can "bland out" the true flavors sometimes.

text:
My accidental modification:  I didn't read the recipe closely before I went to the store, so I only came home with one can (98% fat free) of mushroom soup.  After reading others' reviews, I simply added a can's worth of (regular) sour cream.  I also added about 1/3 cup of (n/f) milk, because others had said the casserole was dry.  Also, I substituted bread crumbs for the potato chips and threw a little parmesan on top.

It turned out really delicious!  It didn't taste low fat.  I think maybe it was even better for having the sour cream instead of the 2nd can of soup -- it helped keep the casserole from having that "canned food" flavor.  And it was firm but moist.  I love onions and don't mind the crunch from raw or nearly-raw onions, but if you don't care for that crunch I'd suggest sweating the onions before baking.

i made this a few weeks ago and my family was kinda "blah" about it, it was the first and only tuna casserole i have ever tried or made. so i didnt want to give up on the idea of a cheap and easy dinner with tuna(my family LOVES tuna so i gave it another go around but this time i changed a few things instead of using a whole 12oz bag of wide egg noodles i used 6 oz macaroni noodles, boiled them and used only 1 can of cream of mushroom and a splash of milk, 1/2 cup of frozen peas added 1/2 cup shredded cheddar, didnt add mushrooms. and used very finely chopped onions as the recipe called for and only one can of tuna. topped it with crushed potato chips then another 1/2 cup shredded cheese and it was so good!! it wasnt dry and it was the perfect amount for my very hungery small family! will make this version again!!!

Alison Alfredson

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Like many other reviewers, I have been making tuna casserole forever. My base ingredients have always been the same to this recipe, and probably a bit less fattening, but I have to say that this one tastes much better! The 2 cans of soup, white onion and cheese really make the difference. I love the egg noodles since they are so light versus twists or tube pasta. I had cream of chicken and mushroom on hand and I think that flavor combo was great. I did mix most of the cheese in and then just used a little on top with a tiny bit of finely crumbled fried onions. I never use those, but since the original recipe called for chips I figured this was the same idea. It was so yummy. 5 stars for me. I am making my second batch today for a reunion potluck. I found that last time putting the casserole in the frig for a couple hours and then cooking it let the flavors set a while. It was a hit for adults and little kids.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this is a 3 star recipe before alterations, and a 5 star after some changes!  I added 1 8oz. containter of light sour cream, and 1/2 cup milk to the recipe, and it was a perfect consistency.  Not too dry or wet.  The sour cream gives it a nice flavor so it's not as bland.  I also mixed the majority of cheese in with the casserole, it would not be enough with just 1 cup.  And then I added a little extra cheese on top.  i also cooked the onions beforehand in a pan so they were soft.  You might need to add a little salt and pepper to this as well.  I used Ritz crackers on top only because I didn't have potato chips, but I'm sure the chips would be excellent.  After these alterations the recipe was wonderful!  Next time I will try 1 cup cheddar and 1 cup shredded velveeta cheese, I think that may add a nice flavor as well.

scoutwidow

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such a delicious, flexible recipe! If you like more tuna, add more tuna!  If you don't like peas, leave them out! If all you have is dried onions, they work fine. I particularly liked the cheese in it as my old recipe didn't have it.  I don't use peas or mushrooms as my kids won't eat them.  I leave them on the side.

I usually add a half cup or so of milk to keep it from drying out since the noodles often absorb more liquid as it bakes.
 
And I have tried it topped with bread crumbs, chips, or plain cheese (depending on what I have) and it's always good.  My favorite is to leave out the onions and top it with French Fried Onions instead.  The flavor and texture are wonderful.

text:
Very good base.  I would give it 5 stars w/ these suggestions for health and flavor:

Use plain greek yogurt instead of more soup to make it a bit moister.  I used 3/4 c.  

Make your own cr. of mushroom.  Extremely simple, quick (we're talking 5 minutes) and MUCH better for you and those you love.

Instead of potato chips, I crushed almonds in the food processor.  Great crunch, when toasted on top.  

Thanks for sharing!

text:
Delicious recipe. I love to find dinners that I almost always have the ingredients to prepare. I too like other reviewers baked in a greased 2 QT round casserole dish. I improvised with what I had which was a combo of sharp cheddar, velveeta and sliced swiss on top. I also didn't have any potato chips. I used part seasoned bread crumbs and french fried onions. Added about 1/4 cup milk and miracle whip after another reviewers suggestions. Added about 1 tsp of garlic powder. Mine wasn't dry at all but I did add milk and miracle whip so that could have helped. Overall great recipe. I did like the slight crunch of the onions and the addition of the can of mushrooms. I think it's great to find a recipe that you can modify based on what you have in your kitchen. You can't beat the price of what this dish costs to make.

text:
Wonderful. Even my picky in laws really liked it (my father in-law is a steak & potato guy), and that's saying a lot! I didn't have peas, so I added chopped baby carrots instead. I made a huge pan of this casserole by adding more tuna, another can of soup, using a pound of penne ('cause that's what I had on hand), and buttered Italian bread crumbs with freshly grated parmigiano reggiano on top. I love how versatile this recipe is. You can add  and substitute so easily. Even if you're kitchen-challenged you can make this and make it great!

text:
Better than tuna helper.  I adjusted the recipe after reading reviews on it being too dry.  I added 1 cup of sour cream and 1 cup of milk as well as 2 tsp powdered chicken soup base and some pepper for additional flavor.  I also increased the mushrooms to a full can and sauteed it with the onion with 2 cloves of garlic and margerine.  Awesome!  My 13 and 15 year old sons both enjoyed it.

text:
My husband said that this tuna casserole was better than his mom's! I made a few changes, but nothing major. I halved most of the ingredients for just my husband and I and it still made plenty. I added some green onion and celery. Increased the peas a bit. Since other reviews said the casserole was somewhat dry, I added 1/2 soup can of milk and a big dollop of fat free Miracle Whip. I also added some dill which was a noticeable and very nice addition. It made the flavor more complex. This is a keeper!

Yummy, just like my grandma used to make it.  I sauteed the onions, in a little butter,  until tender and then added all the ingredients except the noodles.  I also added a little milk to get the consistency I wanted.  I slowly added the noodles and quit adding when they were all coated and not too dry.  The potato chips covered with the cheese made this casserole!  Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
I've been making almost the same recipe for years.  It's my husband's and my favorite standby when we really don't feel like cooking.  Couple things I do - I have oven safe cookware, so I use my large skillet put everything together in it and just put it in the oven.  I too only use one can of soup, but add a cup of milk.  Plus, I used Penzy's toasted onions instead of chopping my own.  Since I don't care for the peas, but my husband does, I leave them out and he gets them on the side. I save some of the cheese (use sharp cheddar for the best flavor) to put on top with the Fried onions instead of potato chips.  We have this at least once a month or more.

text:
Great starting point!  :)  I made mine starting with this recipe, but made a few changes.  I used 1 can of cream of celery & 1can cream of mushroom instead of the 2 cream of mushroom.  I also added 1/2 a container of pimentos, 1 can evaporated milk, mixed veggies, and I didn't have any potato chips, so I did 2tbsp of butter w/ 3/4 c italian bread crumbs.  I also didn't have any egg noodles so I used roughly 2 c (dry) elbow macaroni (cooked). :)  It was great! :)

text:
Tasted pretty good, fast and easy, too! I followed the recipe exactly the first time, liked the taste, but thought the casserole was a little dry. Next time, i used a family size (26oz) condensed cream of mushroom soup, which was a little more than the recipe called for, i got the creamy texture that i love! even when i heated the leftovers up the next day, it was just as creamy. I didnt have regular potato chips the first time, so i used baked lays, the chips browned way too quickly, should use regular potato chips that are nice and greasy, i did that the 2nd time, and it came out perfectly, creamy casserole with a crunch!

text:
Sautéd onion & garlic. Mushrooms, sautéed. 1/2 chicken bouillon cube, optional depending on total salt. Thyme, dill or marjoram. Red pepper flakes.  Dash nutmeg. Sherry.  Omit the canned soup and use sour cream, yogurt, or cream cheese instead of a flour roux. Spinach. Now, add the Tuna - mix with pasta. Top with Cheddar and Parmesan, crushed potato chips (applewood smoked bacon!) and grated Asiago cheese. 25 mins @350.

Display Name:
mmoses

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1517351.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this as a jumping off point, then did my own thing.  So, as it's written I think it would be bland and dry, but the tweaks make it. I omitted mushrooms.

I mixed one can each of cream of chicken & cream of mushroom; I added a can of evaporated milk. Spices:  celery salt, paprika and garlic salt.  Heated all this up then added the shredded cheese; making a great cheese sauce.  
Poured it over 3 cans of well drained tuna, rinsed frozen peas and my onions - which I caramelized. Seriously, there is nothing better than caramelized onions.  
For the topping I crushed up potato chips and dried onions.
This makes enough for a family of 4 to eat for two days, easily.  Even with seconds.  It's creamy and flavorful!

text:
It is the Best.  When I drained the tuna, I saved the juice in a measuring cup, added milk to make one cup liquid, and made a white sauce, stirring it into 2 tablespoons of melted butter and 2 tablespoons of flour, while the cassarole cooked.  I served the white sauce over the cassarole.  Very good.  Be sure to crush the potato chips fine - they can be sharp after baking.

userID:
1168865
Display Name:
Therese Nicole
isPro:

14

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1126570.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good base recipe but I made so many changes to suit our taste. As written, I could see that it would end up dry. I incorporated all the cheese which included Gouda and extra sharp cheddar, then added bit of white cheddar on top. I used fresh mushrooms but canned peas and added diced garlic. The onion, garlic and mushrooms were sautéed in butter. When mixing all the ingredients, I used a family size can of soup, and still found it to be way too dry. I added 1/4 a cup of sour cream and splashes of milk. Instead of potato chips, I used regular panko breadcrumbs sautéed in butter with chives and red pepper flakes. I tasted the mixture and it was bland, so I added salt, black pepper, cayenne pepper, and Old Bay. Once I had the mixture in the 9x13 dish, it still looked too dry so I splashed it with a bit more milk. Finally, I added the white cheddar on top, then the panko, and baked it for about 20 minutes at 400 degrees. Delish! It's definitely a grown up version of tuna casserole with added flavor and texture.

text:
I am revising my review  I have  just made this  recipee  accept  I  used sour cream  milk and an extra can of soup ..I cooked this  at 375 instead of 425 for  30 minutes  and not only did it taste good but it was far from dry..I believe alot think baking at higher temps makes the  food cook faster but  instead it dries out  the food  usually  . it is better  to cook something slower and have it come out tasting greate then   aim to cook faster also keep in mind  tuna  soaks in  moisture  and also mushrooms are  like a spong  soaks in flavors very easily.. So I recamend  lowering the temperature  to now higher than 400F

text:
I love making this to get rid of ingredients in my fridge!  I usually throw in whatever frozen or fresh veggies I have on hand, and cut out the mushroom since my family doesn't like them.  I usually add about a cup of skim milk to make it a little creamier and not quite as thick.  Definitely use lowfat cream of mushroom soup - you can't taste the difference between that and the full fat version, so you might as well save calories!

This is an A+ recipe!! I did have to modify only because I didn't have all items. I used a jar of Alfredo Sauce instead of the cr mushroom soup. I seasoned it up a bit with some dry onion, garlic powder and black pepper. Topped it all off with crushed BBQ chips. I know it sounds odd to add BBQ chips but it came out PERFECT! Everyone ate till they were full, and even my one child who claims to not like Tuna Casserole LOVED this recipe!

text:
This recipe is delicious! Based on other reviews, I added 2 tablespoons light mircle whip and that helped to keep it moist for left overs (I made the recipe to bring as my lunch to work). I also added diced carrots, celery, black olives and becuase I'm health conscious, I omitted the bread crumbs and cut the amount of cheese in half. Add italian seasoning and a tiny bit garlic powder and it will even taste great cold!

text:
We love Tuna "hotdish" as we call it in Minnesota.  My recipe omits the onion and mushrooms.  To make it creamier, add another can of soup:  I use one cream of mushroom and one cream of chicken.  We prefer Albacore Tuna in large packet.  Add about 1/4 cup of milk and a teaspoon of "Better than chicken boullion"  mix it all up really well in a round casserole dish and skip the cheese on top of the chips.

I have never had tuna casserole before, I made this one, and the family loved it. I added what other people mentioned, some milk, sour cream, and mayo for the zip, and I personally love mushrooms so i used fresh sliced mushrooms that I sauteed, and I also sauteed the onions. I also used young sweet peas instead of regular peas, the kids like them better because you don't even know your eating them. I used PANKO bread crumbs with melted butter and garlic toasted over stove top for the toppings. Thank you all for the wonderful advice.

I made this for dinner tonight and it was delicious!  I had some minimal modifications but I don't think they would have changed the flavor of the original dish too much.    1) I made half the recipe but it was still huge and could feed 6! 2)  I followed everyone's recommendation to add some milk 3) added chopped fresh mushrooms, celery, and carrots since we like veggies 4) I used cream of mushroom with roasted garlic since I didn't have the plain mushroom handy. 5) misread the recipe and mixed the cheese in with everything instead of using it as the topping.    Eazy recipe and I highly recommend it!

This was really good! I was just making this for myself, so I made the following changes bases on serving size and ingredients on hand: I used 1 of the small cans of tuna (3oz.), 3/4 can of cream of Chicken(had no mushroom), about 2 cups noodles cooked, and I eyeballed the cheese- about 1 big handfull.. I skipped the veggies, and replaced the onion AND chips with French's French fried onions. That was a great substitution that gave some crunch and flavor, without the overpowering of uncooked onions. Baked it in a small corning ware dish 15 mins, it was wonderful!

Made the recipe twice.  Changes I made:    1.  Added 1 cup of s. cream  2.  Sauteed onions, will be crunchy of you skip this step.    3.  Used fresh mushrooms and sauteed with onions  4.  Fresh Garlic added to sauteed veggies  5.  Ritz crackers instead of potato chips  6.  Dash of cayenne, dried thyme, pepper and salt    The dish would be pretty flavorless without the garlic and spices, especially since there is no pepper in the recipe.  My husband is a big fan of casseroles, and I have learned to live with them... there is another recipe for this casserole made from scratch and I think I might try that next time.

Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2008-09-29T13:03:00.37
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
2086984
Display Name:
Snowbuddy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
737
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/883584.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You have to cook the onions first! 20 mins in the oven is not enough time to cook raw onions. 
I saute them in olive oil for a minute, add fresh chopped mushrooms for a minute, then add the frozen peas and sauté until the onions are almost see-through. Then you mix veggies with noodles, tuna and soup in your casserole dish. I always top with Sea Salt & Vinegar chips (Miss Vickie's). Also, I only cook the noodles for half the regular time, otherwise they get soggy. I often forget the cheese and it's still great. 
Sautéed celery is also a delicious addition. 
You can add a pack of onion soup mix or use it as a topping instead of chips. 
Leftover kale chips have been a good topping as well, and a healthy addition. 
I forgot to cook the onions once and it was horrible. I don't know how so many people have been liking it like that.

text:
I made the recipe for dinner tonight and my husband thought it was great.  He went back twice after the first plate.  I did take some suggestions from other reveiws and added milk.  I think I added around a cup.  I also added salt because I tasted the mixture and it was a little bland.  I used Campbells golden mushroom soup.  I also added around a teaspoon of curry powder. I like the tast because I have used it in chicken casserole dishes.  I did not have any mushrooms but didn't missed them.  I used a combination of crushed potato chips and townhouse crackers.  I covered with foil and baked since some reviews recommended it.  Overall I will definitely make this dish a definite future meal option.  Thanks for sharing.

userID:
11572463
Display Name:
Jolene
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With the Arctic blast moving in I didn't want to go to the store for the mushroom soup so I improvised. You'll need 1.5 cups of milk and 1/2 cup of half and half, (if you don't have half and half use 2 cups milk) 1/2 cup chicken broth or 2 tsp. chicken base to 1/2 C water, 3 Tablespoons regular flour, 1/2 teaspoon dried thyme, 3 Tablespoons butter, 6 oz can of mushrooms (sliced), salt an pepper to taste. Combine butter and flour to make a roux, whisk into the chicken broth and milk mixture until all the lumps are gone. Slowly heat in adequate size saucepan by adding the remaining ingredients whisking as you go. Cook on med. heat, stirring as you cook until desired thickness. The rest of the above recipe I followed to the letter.  
*If the mixture is too thick add more milk or water. Too thin, add 1 Tablespoon flour to 1/4 C cool water, whisk and add to mixture.

text:
I usually don't write reviews about recipes but I felt this one merited one. With a few modifications, this recipe can be a real hit. Super easy to make. I took notes from other peoples suggestions and sauteed the onions in a little bit of butter, added some garlic to the onions and threw the peas in there so they would absorb some of the flavor. I also added about 1/2 cup of Miracle Whip to the recipe. This made a huge difference.  I also added bread crumbs instead of potato chips. I didn't have to add milk to mine. If you add enough Miracle Whip, you will get the tangy flavor and it won't be dry My husband who is not crazy about Tuna, absolutely loved it and had thirds!

I had a very similar recipe from a 1950's cook book, that I have not been able to find, so I was happy to find this one. This is a good stick to your bones casserole, & great for folks on a budget. text:
It was a yummy dish. I used a little bit more cream of mushroom soup as advised by other reviewers. Instead of two 10.75oz cans I used one "family size" 26oz can. I found the casserole to be plenty moist and not dry at all. If I make this again I will probably ad a bit more cheese mixed in, and bake it at a lower temperature for a longer time. 
I normally use Italian bread crumbs as the topping for my tuna casserole, but went with the potato chips this time. My husband and I both agreed that we like the bread crumbs better. 
The only thing I really did not like, was the onions. I'm usually an onion fan, but with the short cook time in this recipe my onions did not cook at all, and they were still totally crunchy and very potent. In the future I will probably use onion powder.

text:
I've made this several times. I've used the pimento cheese with jalapeno vs. any other cheese. It gives it an awesome kick! I use kettle cooked jalapeno chips and no yolk egg noodles and a smaller package vs. 12 oz.  I increase the mushrooms too. I also recommend a round casserole dish vs. flat 9x13 dish, don't want the dish too dry. Add Sriracha before cooking or add before eating. I like it spicy! Lady Di

I made this recipe tonight and read several of the reviews before making it.  I sauted the onions first, but left out mushroom(we are not a big fan of mushrooms) I cooked egg noodles, then I mixed 1 can cream of chicken and 1 can of cream of celery- each with a can of milk.  I added cheese in the soup mix.  Then combined the soup mix with the egg noodles, tuna, and peas.  I topped it with crushed ranch croutons and a little more cheese.  My hubby definitely loved loved loved it.

text:
I only rated this 4 stars..since like others I made some slight modifications to the original.  But it was delicious and so simple to make!!
I added some sour cream to alleviate the dryness others spoke of..and cooked it at a lower temperature for about 20 minutes and it came out creamy and far from dry.
I omitted the mushrooms but loved the suggestion to add some cayenne pepper ...what a great little kick it added!
I always use sharp/old cheddar cheese as I love the stronger flavour..and i added it all into the main ingredients ..not in the topping
I used a Ritz cracker topping .. but that was what i had on hand ..and it was equally yummy..although now i want to try some of the other suggestions.
Overall, it would definitely make it again..and perhaps this time I will mix things up and try some new ideas.

city:

region:

country:

text:
DELICIOUS--with a few tweaks as suggested by other reviewers.  I also usually just wing it when it comes to making this casserole but my husband and family have never been huge fans.  I used 2 cans of cr. of mush soup, 1 can of milk, 1 full can of mushrooms pieces and stems so they were smaller pieces, I sautéed the onion in a little butter and dumped the whole thing in with the mixture.  I went a little heavier on the peas because my family loves them.  I also added both cups of cheese into the mixture (as was suggested) and used an entire sleeve of crushed Ritz crackers mixed into a 1/4 cup of melted butter over the top instead of the potato chips...my youngest loves Ritz crackers and it also gave the casserole just a small amount of sweetness that was delicious.  I baked for almost 45 minutes to make sure it was cooked through and bubbly hot.  My boys loved it and my husband ate so much he was uncomfortable afterwards.  This is definitely a keeper and will be on our regular dinner rotation of favorites.

city:

text:
Great Recipe guideline for Tuna Casserole.  I improvised like I usually do.  For the 2 cans of soup... I used 1 can of Campbell's Cream of Mushroom and 1 can of Campbell's Cream of Celery. By accident, I added the 2 cups of cheese into the mix, so I shredded about 3/4 a cup more for the top and crumbled up jalapeno flavor kettle chips for the top (we like spicy foods in this house!)... To avoid dryness I added about 3/4 of a soup can worth of milk!  I skipped the canned mushrooms...  Tented with Aluminum foil for 20 min then uncovered for 3-5 (depending on cheese browness) It Came out Fantastic!   The flavor was nicely layered and the topping was both crisp and flavorful! :)  Definitely saving this recipe as a great guideline for next time since this is great with a little more moisture and fun to improvise!   Thanks for posting this one!!

Great recipe!  Thanks for sharing!

text:
I have a Tuina Casserole recipe similar to this. 
I use Kraft Mac and Cheese, prepared as directed on the box. 
Mix tuna with Cream of Mushroom soup, add fresh frozen green pears, sometimes sliced black olives together. 
I use crumbled Barbeque flavored potato chips. 
Layer in a greased casserole dish, starting with the chips, mac and cheese, tuna, repeat until done, top with the chips so they get crunchy.

text:
Really yummy! A great way to hide the fishy tuna flavor. I added and omitted depending on what I had on hand. I added 1/2 celery, and 1/4 milk to make it a little more saucy. I omitted mushrooms because I was out, but they would probably be a great addition. Also didn't have potato chips so added french onions! Yummy. You can really add and subtract with this recipe and still keep the flavor.

text:
This was very good. I grill fresh Ahi Tuna then set it aside while I make everything else. I use fresh mushrooms and 1 whole onion sauted in a little oil in the same pot that noodles are going to be cooked in. Take them out to boil the noodles. I also added 3/4 cup of sour cream and a little milk. This was NOT at all dry doing it this way.

text:
This was pretty good, but I have to agree with others that it needed a little flavor boost so I added a little Mrs Dash plus about 1/4c of milk and a big spoonful of sour cream (later changed to mayo, better) due to the comments about it being dry.   I suggest sharp cheddar in casseroles, better flavor when baked.  I didn't have chips on hand so I topped it with some French's fried onions that needed to be used up and that was fabulous!  I'll definitely make it again and experiment, great potential for adjustments to personal taste... it's been a long time since I made a tuna casserole and I did enjoy it.  My 17yo liked it just fine too.

text:
This is a great recipe. As always I made a few changes. I used alfredo sause instead of the mushroom soup because the soup contains MSG. I also added the whole can of mushrooms because the other half would just sit in my fridg. I also added doubled the onion because we love onions. I had onion cheese on hand so that is the cheese that I used to top the casserole with. 
We enjoyed it. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
This definitely reminded me of the tuna noodle casserole my mom used to make. I used one can of fat-free cream of mushroom soup and a can of cream of celery. I added about half a cup of water so the soup mixture wasn't so thick. I also used panko breadcrumbs instead of potato chips to cut down on the fat a bit. I wouldn't say it was dry, but it was still a bit "thick" from the soup. Next time I'll use a little more water or milk. But overall, very tasty recipe.

text:
my mom used to make this. Like others she used a 2 qt. casserole. She also added a 1/2 can of milk to the mushroom soup & heated it on the stove before mixing with the noodles. This did 2 things 1- adding the milk kept it from being dry & 2 - heating everything on the stove distribuated the cheese throughout the casserole better. She also didn't add any potato chips, but it was always super yummy.

This was my first time eating tuna casserole, let alone making it. I didn't know what to expect -- onion? Cream of mushroom soup? Cheddar cheese? All mixed together with canned tuna? It all sounded less-than-appealing to me. But boy, was I wrong. This has an undeniable hearty, homey, comfort food charm to it. I halved the ingredients because I didn't have many mouths to feed, but I did heed the advice of other reviewers and added an extra can of soup and half a can of tuna. I also used a medley of frozen peas, carrots, and corn instead of green peas. Yum!

I make this often, and it is well loved in my house. I sometimes dont add sliced mushrooms, or the potato chips because I dont have them on hand. I have also made it without onion, and it is STILL good! The cheese is a must have. I like to sprinkle quite a bit on top. I sometimes add about 1/4 cup of milk just to make it creamier, it does cook up quite thick. OH I also just use regular noodles. Whatever I happen to have. AND I use a cup of mixed frozen vegetables. It goes very well with it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was super easy. Noone in this house will eat peas, including me. I subbed matchstick carrots. I sauteed them with the onion before adding it to the tuna mixture. The mixture was a little thick, so I added about 3/4 cup of milk. (I didn't measure, I just added a little at a time until it looked right.) I only had a bit of potato chips at the bottom of the bag, so I used half chips and half french fried onions. I really tried to stick to the recipe but these days, you've really got to use what you have on hand and improvise ingredients with what your family will eat. Otherwise, it's wasted time and ingredients. I'll update on how we liked it after dinner. EDITED: Good. My oldest inhaled it. I think I might use a little sour cream or plain yogurt next time, to give it a little twang. This definitely is a make-again dish. The carrots I added were a nice touch.

I rate this lower just because I had to add so many extras to make it so that it wasn't bland. Also, instead of potato chips I used crushed Italian-seasoned croutons. If I had stuck to the recipe it would have been flavorless, in my opinion.

text:
What a great casserole for a cold, snowy day! I read the other reviews and made a few changes. First, I halved the recipe, making a smaller casserole. Then I added onion powder, instead of the chopped onion, because I love the flavor of onion, but do not enjoy chopped onions. I also added a jar of pimento and milk, to make it creamy. I did not have potato chips, so I used Ritz crackers, crumbled on top and drizzled with a little butter. The green peas and pimento made this casserole look very festive. It would be a great casserole to bring to a holiday potluck dinner. Thanks for sharing this easy casserole with us, Jennifer!

This is a very good basic tuna casserole recipe, which is exactly what I've been looking for. text:
I gave this four starts because it is a pretty good base recipe, although I took the advice of others, and I used bread crumbs (garlic and herb) instead of potato chips.  I also added pretty much onion, and a good amount of milk.  This particular recipe dried out a lot without any milk.  I'd suggest adding maybe 1 cup or so.  Also, I added garlic salt and pepper, and a small jar of pimientos.  I made this last night with those revisions (and some extra cheese, and mix all the cheese in, don't put it on top, it gets hard and chewy), and most of it disappeared, very quickly, and I quickly packed the rest for lunch today.

Also, I only had one can of Cream Of Mushroom Soup, so I threw in a can of Cream of Chicken Soup instead, and it added a nice flavor.  Also, the cheese on top dried out quickly-it should probably go underneath the chips.  All in all, a good, easy meal.

Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
4348937
Display Name:
Karen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
454
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/321777.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I like finding strong base recipes like this on AllRecipes that I can adjust based on my family's tastes/needs.  When I found this recipe, I realized that with two growing teenagers,  12 oz. of noodles wouldn't quite work for us, same with the 10 oz. of tuna. Here's how I adapted and everyone loved it! 16 oz. egg noodles 3 cans tuna, 2 cans mushroom soup, 1 can cream of celery soup, 1/2 chopped onion, entire can of mushrooms.  While cooking the noodles, I sauteed the onion and mushrooms  in about 1/4 stick of butter. I poured this all into the noodle mixture to loosen up the noodles so they didn't stick. In a separate bowl, I combined all of the soups, about 3/4 can of  milk, 1/4 C sour cream and approx. 1 t. onion powder and 1-1/2 t. garlic powder. Mixed this all well to combine before adding to the noodles.  Then I added the tuna and mixed it altogether. When I put into a very large 9x13 (high sides) it fit well. I would recommend NOT to add cheese on top of the chips as that made all of the chips stick together, which tastes good, but hard to cut without a knife! And we were watching the Oscars while eating so no knives with us! Not a big deal! Delicious - BTW, I forgot to add the peas, but wound up cooking them separate and serving on the side and we just mixed in as we liked. This will be a keeper in our rotation and I will probably try different the next time, just for fun.

userID:

Display Name:
SeattleSun

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2613695.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good with some adjustments: 

- I used rotini noodles instead because I just like their texture better. They trap the creamy sauce better. 
- I used about a half cup chopped onion and sauteed them in butter 'til soft first (didn't want crunchy onions pieces in my casserole).
- I used the whole 4-ounce can of mushrooms because I mean, why not? 
- I added a little over a 1/2 cup of half and half to combat any dryness. (It was the PERFECT amount of creamy!) I also mixed in some dry boullion to the half and half before adding to the mix. It added some much-needed salt and seasoning flavor. 
- I didn't add the cheese and chips topping right away; I baked the casserole for 20 minutes first, THEN added the cheese and the fried onions (I used those instead of chips. They were still nice and crunchy but also added a lovely onion flavor) and baked for another 5 minutes. 
With all these changes it was probably the best tuna casserole I've ever made. Recommend! (With changes... haha)
-

Great recipe, but gave 4 vs 5 stars since it definitely needed some milk added to keep it from drying out when baking (up to 1 cup).  The onions and peas are optional -- it's just as good without if you don't have on hand.  I added about 1/4 t. black pepper and chose to top it with 2 sleeves of crushed Ritz crackers stirred into 6 T. melted butter vs the chips, but that's just personal preference.    It's a keeper, definitely going into the monthly rotation.

text:
This is crazy easy, but so delicious! My mom learned to cook in France in the 1950s, so of course never cooked with canned soup, but when I made this for the first time,  she couldn't stop raving about how it was the absolute most  fantastic tuna casserole she'd ever had. Then we both howled with laughter when I made her guess what it entailed. Just made it again, because she keeps talking about it.  I used Genova brand albacore tuna in oil/no salt, which is beautiful canned tuna, one can of regular mushroom soup, and one can of cream of celery (why I had that is anybody's guess). I didn't add any extra salt, except to the noodles during boiling, but did add lots of pepper - personal pref.  This is already a regular - THANKS!!!

text:
This was really good. I took the other reviewers advice and made it in a 2qt casserole dish, it was a lot of filling but it fit. 
The things I will do differently next time: saute the onions a little bit before putting it in the mixture. I don't like chomping down on fresh onions (personal preference), I would also cook the mixture for a little bit in the oven before putting the topping on. I felt like the topping cooked and browned up nicely but the mixture underneath didn't get very warm. So those are a few things I would do differently next time. 
My casserole was not dry at all. I did add a dash of milk to each can of soup after I emptied it into the bowl to get all the goodness out of the bottom. I also didn't have potato chips so I used Bugels instead. 
Try this casserole it's so good and will be a staple. The crunchy salty cheesy goodness that becomes the topping is so good.

text:
Made this last night and it was pretty good. I added a cup of sour cream per someone's review, but I wouldn't do that again. It really dilutes the cream of mushroom flavor. But it does need more liquid to keep it from getting dry, so I'd suggest another 1/2 can of soup and 1/2 cup sour cream to add creaminess.  I also doubled the peas (I love peas and rarely eat them). I'd up the onion next time too, like 1/2 of a large onion. If chopped finely, there's no need to saute beforehand, the crunch is nice in my opinion.  French fried onions on top really make this dish!

userID:
22709920
Display Name:
Rodney Koch
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5311155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Read a lot of reviews before I made this.   As stated by others this is a "whats in the pantry" recipe.  There were a few ingredients I didn't have... I substituted cream of chicken for CoM.  No mushrooms either.  I took the advice of others and First  minced & sautéed 1/2 medium onion & 1 large clove of garlic . Then added 1/4 cup dry white wine and reduce.   Once reduced, I added one (1) 10.5oz can of condensed cream of chicken soup, 1 can of whole milk, lowered heat and stirred in 1/2 cup of sour cream, 4oz of cream cheese and 2-3 cups shredded 4 cheese  blend.  The sauce tasted a bit bland so I added 1/2 tsp Worcestershire sauce, 1 tsp lemon juice and 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper; salt and pepper to taste.  I didn't have egg noodles so I used elbow noodles (cooked al dente); placed in oval casserole dish. Poured sauce over noodles added in peas and tuna, mix to distribute ingredients evenly and topped with crushed Italian Seasoned Croutons.  Baked at 425 for 25-30min . Superb dish and easy to make... The whole family enjoyed.  Will definitely be making this dish again.  Perhaps next time I may throw in some pimentos and sliced black olives for color and a more robust flavor.

city:

country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I made the following changes according to the comments I read through along with a couple of ideas of my own :


??used 3 cans tuna
??sauteed mushrooms then added onion, then added liquid ingredients and cheese 
??added one soup can of milk
??added half block of cream cheese
??added about 3 oz of shredded smoked gouda
??used 1/2 cup panko mixed with 1/2 cup crushed chips and reduced cheese topping by half
??baked at 350 for 20-25 min


At the lower temperature i just used a single oven resistant pan to cook my pasta, then the mushrooms and liquids, then mixed all the ingredients into the pan for the final baking step. 


These changes ensured a creamy saucy casserole which we prefer, and the lower temperature is more forgiving on the canned tuna. The second time we made this we added about 6 oz of baby spinach and it worked out great.

text:
What a blast from the past. I made it with one can cream of mushroom + one can cream of chicken and added an extra 4 oz of tuna. Will definitely add more veggies/tuna next time.  Cooked down the onion with 2 cloves of garlic, S&P first then mixed the rest together with the peas, tuna and 1 cup of milk.  It also made sense for us to split it into two different dishes - one round pie pyrex and a second 8 x 8 in for easy storage. Stayed nice and moist under the layer of crispy chips and shredded cheese we added right before baking.

text:
I loved it -- and so did my daughter and husband, but I paid attention to the other reviewers, and made the following modifications:
- I used 2 cans of cream of mushroom soup, 4 oz of cream cheese, and 1 cup of chicken stock (unsalted), which I heated up on the stove top before mixing in. 
- I used Durkee's french fried onions as opposed to a regular onion (mostly because it was what I had on hand, but it turned out well) 
- I used fresh mushrooms versus canned
- I also cooked the noodles only til just tender (about 5 min).

I baked for 20 minutes at 350, and it was fully cooked, creamy and not dry in the least.

text:
I followed others' suggestions and baked @ lower temp (350°) for 30 minutes in an oval Corningware dish covered in foil. I "customized" the recipe by adding half a can of French's/Durkee fried onions and a can of chopped, mild green chiles. I used no milk, a 12 oz can of water-packed Tuna, a can of mushroom soup, Light Miracle Whip (about a cup), a handful of Kraft 2% Mexican 4 cheese grated cheese (mixed it in),  and a can of LeSueur very young early sweet peas (drained). I also used a 12 oz. bag of the No Yolks dumplettes noodles. Topped casserole with crushed Cape Cod potato chips, and it turned out great. Had plenty of leftovers.. Really good & highly recommend!

text:
This is very good.
I made 3 changes: -A can of sweet peas (instead of frozen), -A large can of the cream of mushroom soup (instead of 2 small), & -1 pkg Fresh mushrooms, chopped (instead of canned)

I cooked the noodles & then everything else on the stove, in a big skillet: Butter-flavored cooking spray with the chopped onion & mushroom (~4 min), then added the soup, peas, tuna, cheese.  Mixed in the cooked noodles.  Tossed everything into the 9x13 baking dish.  Covered with cheese & the crushed (sour cream/onion) chips.  Baked 15 min, just to get the top crunchy.
This made a HUGE casserole.  Next time I'll make a half recipe.
Very good (& I only "tolerate" tuna).  Husband really liked it & my one year old was even picking peas off my plate (to eat, not throw :-) ).  I'll make this again (just less next time :-) )!

[Made this again.  Next time I'll use canned chicken instead of tuna.  More palatable to me.]

Display Name:
SeeJae

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was good! Loved the crunchy texture added by the crushed chips. I followed the recipe ALMOST exactly, which is why I'm only giving it 4 stars. Obviously this casserole, as others have said, will come out very dry unless you deviate from the recipe. Mine turned out great. Here's the changes I made: added 3/4 cup of milk, used Mozzarella cheese instead of Cheddar, and left out the chopped mushrooms. We also used carrot/pea frozen mixture instead of just peas (minor change). I think the Mozzarella cheese made the dish taste amazing, and the extra milk really helped the casserole come out creamy without being runny. I would not use cream, as it would be too heavy, but you could add an extra can of soup if you want. Personally I think the milk is perfect, but to each their own. It's a great recipe, but it needs a few tweaks to be delicious. With my changes I would give 5 stars, but I am giving the base recipe a 4, as I do not want readers to have their expectations of this recipe skewed. There are too many reviews that are 5 stars "with all my changes to make it better", and that's not a good way to rate a recipe - you are left searching through reviews for the changes that turn the recipe into something delicious. On its own without any alterations, this recipe will be good, but only 4 stars good. You really need to add some milk or extra soup to turn it into a 5 star dish.

text:
This recipe was delicous but I had a few issues with it. It's dry to counteract this I add half a cup of milk. Egg noodles will soak up liquid and cooking in the oven uncovered will evaporate much of the liquid. I cook the peas first otherwise they are crunchy which we do not like. I used a whole onion, yellow onion as it has more flavor and i sauteed in olive oil first until translucent and a little bit brown and you would be surprised how much flavor they add . No potato chips...nope , I cut in some fresh butter with some seasoned bread crumbs , cover the top of the casserole and then pile on the cheese. I not neatly level off the top of the casserole before adding the bread crumbs, the more uneven peaks, the more crunchy goodness. I used a whole 16 ounce bag of egg noodles.

text:
This recipe turned out really good with a little tweaking. 
Instead of white or yellow onion I used 3/4 cup green onion, fresh sliced mushroom sauteed in 1 tbsp butter until golden brown, added one soup can milk and 3/4 cup starched water from the cooked noodles, 2 tsp Lawry's garlic salt, and 1/2 tsp pepper. 
It came out with a very nice wet to dry ratio and wonderful flavor. My son said "I wish I could come home to this every day."

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really like this recipe.  Peas add a lot to it, in my opinion.  But the crushed potato chips - I think that'd be perfect for a family gobbling the whole dish up in one sitting.  I'm a family of one, never too thrilled about going through all sorts of things just to make a meal, so I like making casseroles like this, and I'll leave the toppings for each dinner I make out of it.  In my efforts to keep the calories and fat down, I usually leave the cheese out of the recipe - and I really don't notice it not being in there, because the overall flavor is what comes through the most.  I grew up always using lemon juice on a serving, and nowadays I buy limes, because they're alway one fifth the cost.  But lemon or lime, and maybe some Romano on a meal is just plain fantastic.  Also, if you're feeling a little daring, add a half teaspoon of hot madras curry powder to the recipe - or a full teaspoon of dill!  Tabasco always seems like a must have with this great dish too! Like my great Jewish friends would say, "try it - you'll LIKE IT!" :-)  This dish is what I call real comfort food.

text:
I love this recipe,but I do change it a bit.  I saute the mushrooms and onions in a little butter before adding it with the other ingredients.  I also add some milk or cream to the mixture to make it less dry.  I usually top the casserole with panko crumbs, since I never have potato chips in the house.  This is comfort food to me.  I feel a little guilty when I make it, since I usually eat much healthier food, but I only make it once a month.

text:
I am only leaving this review for others out there like me who often times don't have the exact ingredients called for in the recipe and need to make substitutions.  I had the basics; pasta, tuna, cheese and onion and wanted a recipe as a guideline and chose this one.  I used rigatoni noodles in place of egg; a can of mixed veggies in place of frozen peas; one can of cream of mushroom and one can of cream of celery; and crumbled Ritz crackers instead of potato chips. I also added a dash of garlic powder.  It turned out fabulous - my husband, Mr. Picky, had seconds, and my reluctant 3 year old finished it off on her own .  I'll be honest, I wasn't sure how it would be but it was great and I'm glad there are leftovers for tomorrow.  Thanks for posting this recipe and giving me the base.

text:
9/14  ... https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/17219/best-tuna-casserole/ ... Ya know ... most of these tuna casserole recipes are very similar, & they're all fine.  I'm thinking a five star one is really dependent on how much you like tuna. (Duh. ;D).  Anyway, I halved this one.  'Short on egg noodles so cooked 2oz spaghetti a couple minutes then added 4oz egg noodles.  "They," the kids, really like that little difference.  Crazy, huh?!  Back to review: I added I guess what was 12oz tuna.  I accidentally bought chunk light & most of that is liquid, which I saved to add some to the dish & the rest to the cat's food.  :)  I used added some "tuna juice" & some milk - approximately a half soup can's worth.  Also added 1/8t cayenne, parsley, onion powder; half cup frozen corn; half cup shredded cheddar in it & another half cup on it.  Topped with bottomofthebag/crushed corn chips & cheezits.  The looks alone got the kids to try it.  (Crazy, the sequel :D).  A little sprinkling of parsley & paprika & wow, they ate it.  Wow. (Wow.)  Note4Me:  Bake in 2qt dish.  at 350.  Add another can o soup & milk/sour cream.  Kinda dry as is.  Maybe cheddar cheese soup. 9/14 K really liked topping with bottomofthebag cheezits & cornchips & the addition of corn.  'didn't say it was tuna.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked this recipe - it makes for a great tuna noodle casserole.  It's one of those "clean out the pantry" recipes where you can use what you have on hand.  For instance, I used whole wheat egg noodles, 98% fat free mushroom soup, and a mixture of cheddar, colby jack and manchego cheeses because it's what was what I had.  I also sauteed the mushrooms and onion in butter before adding them, and dropped the frozen peas in with the noodles at the very end before draining.  As others also suggested, I used the empty mushroom soup can to measure out half a can sour cream and half a can milk, just to ensure it wasn't too dry (and it turned out perfectly).  I, too, just mixed in all of the cheeses, added some cracked black pepper and a dash of salt, and topped the casserole with buttered bread crumbs, as I didn't have potato chips.  Saved and will use again!!

text:
I've made tuna casserole a million times but LOVED this recipe the most.  What makes it is the potato chips. I was pleasantly surprised on how much I enjoyed them.  Previously I only used bread crumbs.  
My alterations:
- I accidently bought 1 cream of mush and 1 cream of chicken. I decided to go with it, and it was AWESOME.
- Used less cheese on top 
- Accidently used the whole package of noodles so I just added a bit more milk, onion, 1 extra can of tuna, and peas to make sure it covered nicely.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good base recipe!  I left out the mushrooms (family doesn't like them) and I used my homemade cream of soup mixture in place of the 2 cans cream of mushroom soup.  I also cut the tuna down to only 1 can, that was plenty for me.  Chicken substituted instead of tuna works really well, too.  I have made this recipe so many times, it is a family favorite for sure!  I forgot the potato chips the last time I made it and it was still good - and I guess I saved a few calories in the process :)  One other thing I do is, during the last minute of cooking the noodles, I add in the frozen peas to the pot to cook them a bit.  Before doing this, my daughter always complained of the icky texture of the peas and this seemed to solve the problem - it is now one of her favorite meals!

This was so easy to put together! I even tweaked it a little, following suggestions from other reviewers. I added a soup can of milk and about 3/4 of a cup of sour cream. I even added more onions because 1/4 cup didn't seem like enough. It turned out nice and creamy, not soupy or dry, and the entire extended family loved it. One member of the fam said he doesn't care for tuna casserole, except occasionally, but this was definitely something he'd like more often. There wasn't anything left for the dog!

Good overall. Four stars because I made necessary changes. I used mostly the same core ingredients. I made a bigger batch, increasing to a 16oz package of egg noodles and three cans of tuna, and bumping everything else up too. I added chopped carrots. Since other reviewers said it was dry I added a cup of chicken broth and it ended up not being dry at all. I also substituted french fried onions for the potato chips on top. It was good but did need a bit of salt and pepper at the table. I'll definitely make this again, but my modified way.

Loved this!  I sautéd the onions in some coconut oil  along with a sprinkle of Webers beer can Chicken Seasoning while the noodles cooked.  I used Targets Market Pantry sweet peas instead of frozen peas and also used the Market Pantry Cream of Mushroom Soup Mix.  Also I used Mexican shredded cheese from Target as I had that on hand.  This recipe is a definite keeper!  The amount is great and will feed my husband and I for dinner all week and I won't have to cook!  Love this recipe and I highly recommend it's super tasty saucy cheesy goodness!
I read some of the other reviews and my creation was not at all dry, it was just the right amount of cheese and sauce and I thought it was absolutely perfect.

text:
This recipe is very good, and I added the following ingredients as well.  I used 1 1/2 pounds 
DeCecco brand Cavatappi pasta (cooked al dente),  12 oz. tuna, along with 2 cans of a condensed mushroom soup, added 1/2 cup milk, 1/4 cup real mayo, 3 oz. crumbled herbed goat cheese, chunked sharp cheddar, chunked white cheddar, mixed it all together, along with adding frozen corn instead of peas.  I shredded the rest of the cheddar on top, added freshly grated parmesan, and crushed potato chips, kettle brand.  We are a family of 6 and everyone was pleased and went back for seconds.  I love this website and get many good ideas and helpful hints.  MALLORY

text:
I was looking for something that both my husband and kids would enjoy eating and came across this recipe.  Since I hadn't made a tuna casserole in years, I thought I'd try it out.  I didn't have cream of mushroom soup, so made a basic bechamel sauce (3T butter and 3T flour with about 2 cups of milk and some chicken stock that I had on hand to add flavoring).  I increased the amount from the ~20oz of soup in the ingredients after reading several reviews recommending more liquid so that it doesn't bake too dry.  Otherwise, I kept the recipe exactly as is.  My family loved it!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Ok, this was delicious! I made just a couple minute changes.
First, in a little olive oil I sauteed onion, 2 cloves of garlic, a handful of chopped fresh parsley and 4 fresh mushrooms chopped. Meanwhile boiling the noodles. After the onions were tender, I added the peas to the same pan and heated through. When the noodles were done I placed them in a bowl with the remaining ingredients and because I had read a few reviews stating the casserole was dry, I added 1 Cup of milk and 1 Cup of sour cream. I also put the 2 Cups of Cheddar in the mixture. I mixed it well and added salt and pepper, and put it into the 9x13 and topped it with an additional cup of cheddar, some french fried onions, and a 1/4 Cup of shredded parmesan, that I had mixed. I baked it for the recommended time and it was FABULOUS! My family of six devoured it!

text:
Kid friendlier version....leave out the onion and extra mushrooms. Add 1/2 cup milk to soup and some black pepper. I too use twice the tuna and only chunk white albacore. Layer noodles, tuna and peas with additional sliced up hard boiled eggs (I use 4 or 5). I warm the soup up first and then pour over layers. My son and husband prefer crushed Ritz crackers instead of chips. I don't add the cheese on top until the last 10 minutes and use about 1 1/2 cups (reduce oven to 375). Hint: spray inside casserole with Pam or equivalent for easy clean up and serving.

text:
This was good, but the ingredient ratios are "off".  Too many noodles/not enough sauce as written.  Try about 3/4 of a 12 oz. bag of noodles, and ADD about 1/4 cup milk and half cup sour cream (or maybe an extra can of soup?).  Also added dill weed and a squirt of lemon juice to bring up the flavor.  Topped with buttered crushed corn flakes in lieu of chips (just what was in the pantry). Then just bake at about 350 for 35 minutes (so the top doesn't burn). Decent idea, but not quite accurate as written.

text:
This recipie turned out pretty good, with some adjustments. It is a great basic recipe! I added one can of cheddar cheese soup,  1 1/2 cup of peas, 3/4 cup milk, a few dashes of pepper and garlic powder. For the topping, I used butter crackers mixed with melted butter (I didn't have potato chips, and I've used the cracker/butter mix before). I also used more than 2 cups of cheese, as I have a cheese loving family. It turned out delicious, and wasn't dried out!

text:
This was the best tuna casserole I've made yet, and my husband loved it! I pretty much followed the recipe with a few exceptions: used a round casserole dish, added an extra 1/4 cup chopped onions, added some heavy cream and milk, didn't drain the mushrooms for added flavor. We like spicy food so we added some sriracha rooster sauce too. Would make again, and tasted great reheated. I think a good tip is to use 1 can light tuna and 1 can white albacore tuna. The albacore chunks make it extra yummy!

This recipe is really great and easy to make.  I followed some of the other reviews and added an extra can of soup and a cup of sour cream.  For the top I also used half crushed potato chips (I used Lays) and then half french fried onions.  It turned out very creamy and then an extra bit of flavor on top.  Next time I may leave out the sliced mushrooms and only use an extra can of soup OR a cup of sour cream and see how that is, just to save on $$.

text:
Changed it just a tiny bit, as have so many others (whom I thank for their suggestions) by cooking the onions in butter to sweat them out, adding 1.5 cups of milk, omitting the mushrooms, adding additional frozen peas, dotting the top of the potato chips and cheese with butter and cooking it at 375 for 30 minutes.  The cheese was bubbly, the potato chip topping was crispy, and the entire dish was creamy and comforting.

text:
I don't generally make this kind of casserole but tried it after all the good reviews.  I am glad I did :-).  I followed the recipe but halved it, and after reading the reviews the only thing I did was to add 1/4 cup of milk to counteract the reported dryness.  I also reduced the heat to 180C and cooked for about 30 minutes.  I was impressed with the end result and will definately make it again but will add my own touches.  The crunchy topping was ok but needs some fine tuning for my taste.  All-in-all a big thumbs up and really quick to prepare.

text:
This really was the best tuna casserole I've ever had. Made just a few modifications..I used rotini, we were out of egg noodles. I used a 26 oz can of cream of mushroom soup, and about 6 oz of sour cream, plus 1/2 cup of milk. I love onion, so I added slightly more, about 1/2 cup. I didn't have enough cheddar, so I used a combination of mozzerella and cheddar.  I don't buy potato chips, so I used panko crumbs instead. This was creamy and delicious, not at all dry. My family loved this, and I think I'll make it exactly the same way next time.

text:
Made a half recipe of this tonight for our dinner.  I grated my onion into the casserole because I didn't think it would get cooked enough and I did also add some milk to keep it moist.  I didn't have any chips, but I did have a half of a can of french fried onions to use up so I put those on top.  This was very tasty and I was able to put this on the table very quickly after work.  For the reviewer who said this was "too bland", don't be afraid to add a little pepper and some garlic powder to this.

Pharmy2012

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/441788.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great. Followed it mostly but omitted the onion and mushrooms, and used drained french-cut green beans instead of peas. Only had one can cream of mushroom soup on hand so I used it along with a can of cream of celery. Pleasantly surprised at how GREAT it tasted!! Added some garlic salt and a few good dashes of pepper. Mixed soup, salt/pepper, tuna, 2 cups sharp cheddar cheese, 1 and 1/4 cup milk, 1/4 cup sour cream, and green beans in a mixing bowl. Added half to bottom of porcelain baking dish, added cooked noodles, then added the rest of the mix on top and slowly mixed in the dish. Added bread crumbs mixed with melted garlic butter on top. Bake 425 for about 11 min (my oven cooks really fast). Viola!! Super. Thanks!!

I really LOVED this tuna casserole! I have never really liked tuna casserole before, but I have been trying new crockpot and casserole recipes and figured "Why not?". I used whole grain spiral noodles, added more cream of mushroom soup, and substituted the chips for whole grain crackers (good carbs). This is excellent with some tweeking.  I made just half a recipe but used two cans of tuna (one was pretty skimpy) and added half a soup can of milk to the soup.  I skipped the mushrooms and used celery instead. Wish I had used more. My only complaint is the number of servings it says it will make.  Six? Forget it!  More like 10 or 12.  Half the recipe is more than enough for six very hungry eaters. Next time I"ll cut it in half again for my DH and me.

text:
incredible!  made a few minor changes. used:  -12 oz pckg egg noodles -2 foil pkgs tuna -3/4 can Kitchen cut greenbeans (diagonal). drained -1 can sweet whole kernal white corn. drained. -1 can cream of mushroom -1 can cream of celery -probably doubled the cheese -3/4 sleeve CLUB CRACKERS :) lightly crunched in a zip-lock  cooked noodles in a skillet while oven preheated. mixed all other ingredients in casserole dish while noodles boiled. drained noodles, added & mixed. then covered with cheese and a thicccck layer of crumbs. baked at 425 degrees for 15ish mins, and whaaalahhhh! omnomnom.  friends proceeded to demolish.
