Normally I make a recipe exactly as written the first time but I had to make a few changes because of what I had on hand and family tastes. I used Colby and Jack cheese because that was what I had and I omitted the peas and mushrooms and added frozen corn and frozen green beans instead because of family preference. I crushed seasoned croutons (I make my own but store bought works too) and spread on top instead of chips because I only had BBQ chips and I thought that would just be gross. This was fantastic!! My husband proclaimed better than my other tuna & noodles recipe which was his mothers recipe! THAT is a compliment! Even the kids ate extra helpings and leftovers! This is definitely a keeper!

text:
I have made this several times now. Absolutely delicious!!! I have made the original recipe, and also tweeked it according to my family's taste or the lack of ingredients in the pantry. This recipe is very forgiving if you are missing peas or canned, sliced mushrooms, try chopped celery. A friend of mine hates anything with mushroom, so I will use cream of celery instead, etc... Also, I enjoy using the Sour Cream & Onion flavored potato chips to sprinkle on top. Next time I will use French's Cheddar Fried Onions. Yummmy!
Review:

country:
None
text:
I added 3/4 cup of milk and a spoonful of sour cream to combat the dryness others mentioned. My problem with the dish was that the onion didn't cook at all inside the mixture so biting into raw pieces was kind of unpleasant (and I normally love onions!) If I made it again, I would saute the onions first and either used canned peas (as opposed to frozen) or substitute for broccoli or asparagus. My boyfriend said "it tastes like Tuna Helper but took you three times as long to make it." I may try it again, but with the changes listed above.

text:
I have a tried and true tuna casserole that I've been using for years.  I made this one based on one single review - she described this as an "adult version" of tuna casserole.  What an accurate description.  It's not overly cheesy, the veggies add a bit of class (as much as tuna casserole can be classy), and overall, it was a good weekday dinner.  The only change I made was using bread crumbs instead of potato chips on top.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe has become a staple in my menu planning.  I add an extra can of tuna for additional protein and 1 cup roughly diced carrots to boost the veggie factor.  I also omit the mushrooms as they are "gross", at least that's what I'm told.  I blanch the carrots in the noodle water just before draining them.  When I was short potato chips and in a pinch I used pancko bread crumbs with 1/4 cup cheese mixed in for some fat. I also used sour cream and onion potato chips which made it a little too salty.  All-in-all, a huge hit!

Great classic tuna noodle hotdish (as we call it in Minnesota). I didn't quite have enough frozen peas so I added a stalk of celery. Only used a couple of tablespoons of onion. text:
This dish was very yummy and easy to make.  I did make a few alterations. I added extra cheese and milk to the noodle mixture along with corn and peas (instead of just peas) and added more cheese to the top of the mixture with bread crumbs instead of potato chips. The extra milk and cheese really helped with the "dryness" problem that everyone else has been talking about. I do want to try it with potato chips on top - i just didn't have them handy at the time. I was a little scared about adding the can of cream of mushroom soup to it because neither me nor my husband like mushrooms but fortunately we couldn't taste them at all! Overall it was a very tasty dish and i will make it again. :)

Thanks for the great starting point! I admit I totally switched things around.... Since I only cooked for 2, I halved it. I used a 2 qt glass dish. I used 1 can cream of mushroom, 1 can tuna, 1/3 box of cooked rotini. 1/4 c heavy cream. 2 Handfulls of cheddar. No chips on top, no peas. 2oz jarred sliced mushrooms.**DEFINATELY use red onion**  I found that broiling it toward the end made the top very tasty (make sure you top it with a layer of cheese before cooking). No fancy seasoning needed, just good, creamy and cheesy tuna noodle casserole!

text:
My husband wanted a tuna casserole like his mother used to make so he found this recipe and made it for me.  I was shocked at how good it was.  The only tuna casserole I've ever had was fishy and icky tasting.  This one was creamy and delicious.  He did add a couple of tablespoons of miracle whip for extra zing and used french fried onions instead of potato chips because that is what his mother always did.  We will definitely be making this one of our go to quick recipes.

text:
Yum! I love tuna casserole and I've been searching for something I love as much as the stuff out of the box (ha). This was really delicious!   Here are my only changes: I used whole wheat egg noodles.I used 1 can of mushroom soup and 1 can of cheddar soup (I like my tuna casserole cheesy). I omitted the mushrooms and peas because I don't like them. Used the onion, though I added a little fresh garlic. Oh, and I used food processed cheddar french fried onions instead of chips, since I really don't like chips.   This is a great recipe and easily tweaked to suit the tastes of the people in the house. Thanks! It's a keeper!

text:
REALLY good and easy and adaptable. I used 1 can cr of mushroom, and 1 can cr of chicken, since that's what I had.  Added 1 can milk as others suggested.  I added 1 1/2 cans mushrooms, as we are mushroom lovers.  Mixed the cheese in rather than put half on top.   Also I had no egg noodles or potato chips, so I used shell noodles and buttered seasoned bread crumbs for the top (which made a nice crunchy crust). Added approx. 1 tsp salt, and 2 tsp pepper, and 1 tsp celery seed for flavor. I have been resisting making *any* tuna casseroles, since my mother made the most awful tuna casseroles for us as kids(lol).  My boyfriend sort of dared me to try one, and I'm glad I picked this recipe! I noticed a few reviewers did not like the onions, but we thought they added good flavor and texture.Really good and so easy.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My family and I absolutely LOVEEEE this recipe!! I've made it about 3 time snow. I read and followed the other user review's once, followed the recipes as is once, and then did my own alterations. The user reviews turned out to be very helpful with my own alterations. I omitted the mushrooms, we're not a big fan, and felt there was enough in the mushroom soup. I sauteed the onion in 2TBS of butter until tender then I mixed it with the peas and used 1 can mushroom soup, 1 can cheddar soup instead of the 2cns mushroom. I also mixed in 1/2 can milk and 1 cup of sour cream, it was very creamy not at all soupy, but with the perfect consistency. I also sprinkled in about 1 tbs of salt, 2tbs of pepper, and 2tbs of garlic powder. I sprinkle the cheese on before sprinkling on the lays original potato chips. This recipe gets a RAVE review from me and have been asked for the recipe from out company pinic! Thank you for sharing!

country:
None
text:
Overall, very tasty. However, I think that 425 is too high of an oven temperature... it got too hot and more burned on top than I would have liked to see it and despite adding in extra moisture (3 cans of soup!) as other reviewers recommended it was still a little on the dry side. I'll make it again because I love tuna casserole and I liked the fresh onions, but I would keep it covered and bake for 35-40, remove cover and bake an additional 5 minutes to toast the top. Also, did 1/2 topped with potato chips and 1/2 topped with French Fried Onions and both my boyfriend and I preferred the French Fried Onion topping much more.

Display Name:
nursevespa

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this lastnight for my husband, who really doesn't care much for tuna.  He cleared his plate, twice, but wasn't raving about it.  It really is a great comfort food type of meal, but I'll admit something felt like it was missing.  After reading previous reviews, I knew to add milk, I added about 1 1/4 cans of milk.  Mine wasn't dry at all.  I also discarded about 1 1/2 cups of cooked noodles.  I used extra cheese in the casserole, and less on top (which I added in the last 10 minutes of baking).  I used green beans instead of peas, which may have contributed to it needing more salt and flavor.  I will definitely make this again, but will use more cheese, more salt and pepper, and will add miced garlic as well.  FYI, I'm having the leftovers as I write this -- they're almost better because the onions have now permeated the casserole.  If you plan on having some left for later don't top that area with potato chips when you bake it, add them after you reheat.

I don't know why I forgot to rate this - but - I've been using this recipe for a long time.   My other half thinks it's the best tuna casserole he ever had.   I also found out that it freezes well.   At least that what he tells me.   I freeze it in small containers for lunches and then he takes it to work.

I like the fact that it's really easy to put together.   I use 1 can of cream of celery with 1 can of cream of mushroom.   I think it gives it a bit of a different flavor.

I also took others advice and add about 1/2 cup of milk.

Very good.

text:
I made this using reduced fat/sodium cream of mushroom and cream of celery soup and I also substituted fresh mushrooms for the canned.  After reading the other reviews, I added about 3/4 c. milk to make it moister. I didn't like the way it tasted hot out of the oven, but leftovers the next day, and the next were tastier and the addition of peas really makes the difference, I think.  I forgot to add them in when I put the casserole in the oven, so I served them as a side dish.  This recipe didn't knock my socks off, but it was okay.  I liked the addition of potato chips for the topping.

We ate it (any time my husband will eat something multiple times it is a success) but it was tasteless.  Wasted expensive tuna ($5.00/can).  Should have been called  noodle casserole as that was pretty much all you could taste.  It was really, really dry, like shoe leather.  I used a Pyrex dish and it did not heat the dish all the way through even though I lowered the heat and left it in longer.  It was lukewarm with cold spots.  Pyrex also had some hot spots on the glass so won't use it again.  All in all, a disappointing dish (and container).  Just happy my husband ate it.

text:
I just made this and I want to say that it is NOT anywhere CLOSE to being the best of anything. 

I thought it was really strange that the mushrooms and onions weren’t supposed to be cooked in a skillet beforehand. I was right. It was strange. The mushrooms were still raw and the onions were crunchy. That part was awful. 

I read reviews before making it and it needed so much tweaking to the recipe that it wasn’t even the same recipe anymore. I didn’t have an additional can of soup, since the recipe only called for two. So I saved the recipe by adding about 2 cups of chicken broth because that’s all I had on hand. 

I added an additional can of tuna, pepper, garlic powder, salt, more peas, and cayenne. It would have been good after all of that if I had followed my instincts and cooked the stupid vegetables first.

text:
This is a good recipe I will keep!  I did make a few changes though, I use a can of cream of mushroom and a can of cream of chicken, I added probably 1/2 c more peas, I eyeballed it, but I added probably 1/2 t garlic powder, 1/2-1 t onion powder, 1/4t chili powder, 1/8 t red pepper flakes & kosher salt and pepper to taste.  Instead of using crushed potato chips on top, I used Panko, then drizzled a little (maybe 1 T) melted butter on top then sprikled a little kosher salt top after the cheese.  It turned out really good!

I made lots of changes since I was repurposing leftovers.   I used 1/2 the amount of egg noodles, celery instead of peas, cream of chicken soup, no mushrooms, salt, pepper, and I added dill.  I topped it with sour cream and onion flavored chips.  I used a 9x13 pan and covered it with foil.  The texture and moistness were perfect!  Not dry at all and the celery added great crunch.  The flavor was still slightly bland.  I'll add more spices and seasoning to it next time.

text:
I wasn’t too enthused when my husband requested Tuna  Casserole for dinner. It did not look appetizing either. I followed the recipe but I used fresh mushrooms and sautéed them in butter. I boiled the noodles and added better than bouillon roasted chicken base for added flavor. Drained noodles mixed a little butter in. I mixed all other ingredients together with most of the cheese. I added a little more than a 1/2 cup of sour cream and a half cup of milk. When I added in my sautéd mushrooms I kept butter it was sautéed in and the tuna was added without draining. I turned my oven on to 350 baked for 15 min covered with foil then added oyster and soup crackers and rest of cheese on top and baked for another 12 min

text:
Five stars - with the following changes.  I used Gruyere instead of cheddar and sauteed the onion before mixing in.  I also used homemade condensed cream of mushroom soup from Pioneer Woman recipe, and eliminated the canned mushrooms.  Lastly I used fresh whole wheat bread crumbs instead of chips.  Based on other reviews warning of dryness, I baked at only 350 degrees for 30 minutes, and covered the dish with non-stick aluminum foil for the first 20 minutes.  Fabulous!  The whole family agreed this recipe will go on our "rotation".

text:
I loved this recipe as I am generally a lover of pasta and white sauces and cheese.  I wasn't in the mood for peas, so I omitted them, then added a handful of chopped green onions.  I also put mozarella instead of cheddar because I already had it on hand grated. I knew this needed a kick, so I checked other websites and found that these spices make it game changer: 1 tsp dried basil, 1 tsp dried oregano, 1 tsp mustard, 1 Tablespoon worcestershire sauce. I had homemade  pureed broccoli soup on hand, so I added 5 cups of that. I covered them in crushed Bugles (popular in the 80's!) and baked half hour. A lot of changes, but this recipe was the base I needed. Thank you!

My picky family enjoyed this and my husband asked for seconds and said "yum, this is really good!"  I used 1 can cream of mushroom, 1 can cheese soup, and 1 can cream of celery. I did end up salting it a little.  Very yummy!!

None
text:
This is our favorite recipe for tuna casserole! We make it at least once a month and there is always leftovers. It's super budget friendly and very easy to make. I occasionally switch out cream of mushroom for cream of chicken, still turns out great. The only thing missing from this recipe is more seasoning, but that's up to preference. We also prefer using jalapeño flavored potato chips as it gives more flavor, I've found that kettle chips work best and stay crisper.

text:
I make this all the time with some changes. I use 1/2 bag of noodles to keep the casserole from drying out. I omit the peas and mushrooms but sauté celery with the onion. I season with garlic powder, celery salt, pepper, paprika, and lots of dill! I also incorporate the cheese into the casserole. I use crushed jalapeño chips on the top! My fiancé and kids request this almost once a week! I usually serve green beans on the side!

Display Name:
Briana King

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2692760.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is just like the casserole my mom made when I was little. 

However, I don't use condensed soup. Instead, I make my own cream of mushroom, and it's so easy! Melt a half a stick of butter in a sauce pan and whisk in 1/4 cup of flour.  Whisk for 3-5 min. then add a cup of beef broth (I just use water and bouillon) and a cup of milk.  Throw in a can of mushrooms and whisk until thick and creamy.   It 's exactly the same but with lower sodium! 

Also, I add the cayenne and garlic powder, and I try to use salt and vinegar potato chips.

Overall I got great reviews from the family.

text:
THE FIRST TIME I MADE IT TURNED OUT DRY AND BLAND. THE SECOND TIME I FOLLOWED REVIEWS.I MIXED I CAN CREME OF MUSHROON SOUP WITH CAN OF CREME OF CELERY IN A LARGE BOWL. I ADDED 1.5 TSP OF GARLIC POWDER, 2 TSP. ONION POWDER,I TSP. DILL,AND 1/2TSP PEPPER. , PEAS, 1/2 CUP SOUR CREME,I/2 CUP MILK, 1CAN(4.5OUNCES) MUSHROOMS &MIXED.I ADDED THE DRAINED TUNA& 3/4 OF CHEESE & MIXED. I COOKED THE NOODLES SOFT, DRAINED & RETURNED TO STRAINER. I HEATED THE MIXTURE IN THE POT & ADDED NOODLES & MIXED AND PUT IN BAKING DISH. TOPPED THIS OFF WITH THE REMAINING CHEESE AND CRUMPLED POTATO CHIPS. BAKED IN 350 PREHEATED OVEN FOR 20-25 MINUTES. YUMMY, YUMMY

I don't know how anyone can say this is too dry. Maybe they are leaving it in for more than 20 minutes. I used 3 times as much fresh mushrooms, instead of canned. I added 2 stalks of sliced celery for some crunch. I served sliced green onions to sprinkle on top and it added a nice fresh flavor.  Way too much food for the two of us. Some in the fridge for later in the week and some in the freezer. We will definitely make this again when the leftovers are gone.

text:
Great recipe. I used rotini pasta, 3 cans of tuna drained, 2 cans of peas drained and 8 oz fresh mushrooms sliced thin. Used what I had - 1 can of cream of mushroom soup and 1 can of cream of chicken soup. I added 8 oz of sour cream and about 1/3 cup of milk. Crushed a sleeve of Ritz crackers and melted 1 stick of butter poured over the top. Cooked in a 9x13 pan. The recipe was delicious and creamy. Will be making this again.

text:
My family enjoyed this recipe, but be warned it is a little bland, even with the changes I made. The changes were: I doubled the tuna, I used 2 cans of cream of mushroom AND added a can of cheddar cheese soup, I sautéed the onions in a little butter, and I added pepper. I also didn’t have potato chips, so I used panko. In the future, I’ll season it with Seasoned Salt and a little more pepper. Otherwise it was a hit, my family loved it.

4 stars because I made the following changes
1- cooked the noodles with garlic powder, salt and small pieces of two celery stalkers until soft
2-mixed the noodles with 1 can mushroom soup and one can of celery soup
3-sautéed 1medium diced onion and the peas in butter

text:
So, I made this casserole twice. The first time I followed the recipe as posted. The results were underwhelming. 3 stars at best. Like other reviewers mentioned, it was very dry with only 2 cans of soup. Also, the onions and peas were still raw after only baking for 20 minutes. Plus, it was just blah. I made it again last night but made some changes. Here's what I added to the ingredient list: 

3 carrots, sliced
2 stalks of celery, sliced
2 tablespoons of minced fresh rosemary

I also used 3 cans of cream of  broccoli cheese soup.

Here's what I did:

As my pasta was boiling I added all my vegetables (including those peas) I let them cook for the last few minutes while the pasta cooked. I drained everything then added it back to the same pot. Then I added my 3 cans of soup & Rosemary. I skipped the chips and just added cheese to the top. Baked at the temp and for the time recommended and it was great!!

text:
The only change I made was using large egg shell noodles and adding a TBSP of sour cream to the mixture (mostly cause I wanted to use the rest of what I had so I could throw it out). Make sure the peas are ready so you can pour the hot noodles over the top. I also sauteed the onion for about 5 minutes then sauteed the mushroom for a few minutes. One mistake I made was topping with cheese then finishing with potato chips, should've been the other way around. The chips get a little burnt that way. The recipe turned out good though and is something I would make again.

Display Name:
Travis

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have all the ingredients the recipe calls for when I made this, but luckily, this is an easy recipe to experiment with. I used rotini instead of egg noodles (I prefer rotini for casseroles), sour cream and onion chips instead of plain chips, 1 can of cream of chicken soup instesd of 2 cans cream of mushroom, and 1 cup of frozen, diced green pepper instead of frozen peas. The result was as delicious as you would expect from a tuna casserole! I think adding peas in addition to the green pepper would be perfect. To make up for the can of soup I didn't have, I added two heaping tablespoons of French onion dip. The result was creamy but not too creamy. Making it again, I'd probably use part cream of chicken and part cream of mushroom. When topping with cheese and crushed chips, make sure to put the cheese on top of the chips or the chips will get too brown during baking. I also added about 1.5 tsps of black pepper. You definitely don't need extra salt in this recipe with the chips and soups that go into it. Overall, a very quick, easy but delicious recipe!

text:
Used 1 can cream of celery, 1 can cream of mushroom, used a whole sweet onion chopped and cooked until soft with a can of mushrooms and some minced garlic.  Added more cheese (mixed in cheddar and a handfull of parm), covered top with French onions and some crushed kettles chips and more cheddar cheese.  Also used 3 cans white albacore tuna.  Added frozen peas and equal amount of frozen white shoe peg corn.   Also added maybe half a cup of sour cream.  Baked at 350 for maybe 25 minutes with foil cover, then turned up to 425 for last 10-15 with cover off.  Best ever.....

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good base recipe.  Since I was making it just for my husband and myself, I cut the recipe in half.  I didn't have cream of mushroom soup, so I substituted cream of celery soup and used a red onion which added some nice color to the dish.  I was concerned that it would be too dry, so I added about 1/2 cup of milk .  I also used french fried onions for the topping instead of potato chips.  I baked the casserole with a cover on it for all but the last 5 minutes.  It turned out  beautifully - a nicely browned and crunchy top with a creamy texture underneath.  It was very tasty!  Will definitely be making this again.

text:
As is this recipe was just basic & on the dry side. I will saute up some mushrooms, sweet onions & orange bell peppers next time. I did not like the chips on top & will use French fried onions instead. As for the dryness I will probably add olive oil mayonnaise & milk if needed. I'm dissapointed that I used my sister-in-law's canned fresh caught tuna on this & am wishing I would have used it for a better recipe.
I am so frustrated with people who rate recipes 5 stars when they make all these changes. Please rate the recipe as is & then say how you improved it to your liking. It makes it hard to find a great recipe by its rating. I wish there were some rules on here.

text:
This is really good and easy! I made a few changes:
1) I added a few sliced carrots
2) Instead of 1/2 can of sliced mushrooms, I used fresh ones
I added these with the frozen mushrooms in the pot with the noodles while the noodles cooked. 
3) Instead of chopped onion, I used onion powder (more because I forgot to cut one and add it!)

Next time, I also believe I will add a little more cheese and maybe use a different time of cheese. Sharp cheddar was good, but another type might be good as well! The melty, crusty cheese on top with the crunchiness of the chips is great!!

text:
I started with the basic recipe, but made some changes. I sautéed the onion with garlic and fresh button mushrooms. To that I added 1 can of regular cream of mushroom soup, and one can of cream of cremini mushroom soup, dill weed, salt and pepper, garlic powder, some milk to thin it out and a touch of siracha for a little kick. Once cooked through, I added it to the egg noodles, peas, tuna, and cheese in the Casserole dish. For the finishing touch and for a bit more dill flavour, I crushed up dill pickle potato chips for the top. It came out flavourful and creamy. Will definitely make this again.

text:
Good recipe, but made even more simple with raw pasta.  I added 2 soup-cans worth of water to the listed ingredients and just put the egg noodles in dry.  Fold gently to incorporate without breaking noodles.  I used a deeper casserole dish (vs. 9x13 pan), so about halfway through the baking time, I stirred again to ensure the "top" noodles got turned down into the liquid.  Added the crunchy topping stuff after stirring.  Noodles all thoroughly cooked with a perfect consistency at the end.

userID:
20542919
Display Name:
Chase Corbin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4018325.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is bland, boring, and designed for children.  Improved the potato chip idea with a recipe designed for adults. See following. 

Ingredients:
- 1lb bacon, fried crisp, with 1tbsp grease reserved.
- 2 (6oz) cans of yellowfin tuna, drained with juice reserved
- 2 (6oz) cans of albacore tuna, drained with juice reserved
- 1 large shallot chopped
- 1/2 medium sweet onion chopped
- 1pt heavy cream
- 2 cans (11oz) condensed cream of mushroom soup
- 3.5 cups frozen peas
- 1 cup + 1 cup cheddar cheese shredded 
- 1 cup Comte cheese shredded
- 2lbs orchiette pasta cooked al dente
- soy sauce, fish sauce, black pepper, old bay to taste
- 4oz potato chips, crushed to crumbs
- 3tbsp butter

Directions:
Fry onion and shallot in reserved bacon fat until tender and translucent. Add tuna, soy, fish sauce, and seasonings fry until well blended.

Chop already cooked and drained bacon, add to onion and shallot mix, and mix well. Let fry 2-3 minutes and add 1-2tbsp butter.

Mix soup, heavy cream, and tuna juice until well blended. Add soup mix to tuna/bacon/onion mix stirring well until blended. Let reduce over low heat, for 8-10mins. 

Pour tuna mix over cooked and drained orchiette. Stir well. Add 1 cup of cheddar and 1 cup of Comte and mix well until cheese is well distributed and melted thoroughly. Stir in peas. 

Butter the bottom and sides of a large, shallow baking dish. Pour pasta and tuna combination into baking dish. Sprinkle 1/2 cup cheddar cheese, then 2oz potato chip crum
Review:
Rating:
4

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out great.  Not dry. I usually made a recipe as written first before making a bunch of tweaks but after reading the reviews about it being dry, I used some suggestions and I'm glad I did.  I made it in a 2-qt round casserole - that was a really good idea. And I used 1 can of cream of mushroom and 1 can of cream of celery - another good idea.  I also had a different recipe that claimed to be the best tuna noodle casserole and in that recipe it said to add 1/2 can of evaporated milk and 1/4 cup of mayo.  So I added that because I figured it could only help with the dryness.  I will be reheating this at work today in a crockpot and I really hope it reheats well especially after adding those extras.  UPDATE: Yep, it reheated just fine.  I poured in a little milk just to be on the safe side and kept it on low to heat through.  Everyone loved it.  No leftovers! :)

text:
This is the 3rd time within 5 mins I am trying to write a review for this dish. On my iPad keyboard the return key is marked DONE for some reason.     .For the ingredients I made the following changes:                                                                                                                                4 cups of shredded sharp cheddar.    3 cups of crushed potato chips.    No peas nor mushrooms.  I used 3 cups of broccoli flowerets which I cooked in boiling water for 2 mins prior to cooking noodles. Be sure to put cooked broccoli in cold water to stop cooking. Also sautéed 3 cloves of crushed garlic in 1 TB of butter.   I also added 1 cup of low fat sour cream to the soup mixture.  Don't cook the noodles until you have mixed the soup etc.    Soup, sour cream, broccoli, 2 cups of shredded cheddar, garlic. - tasted it and added salt & pepper.  Added tuna drained. Mixed it up very gently and then added cooked noodles.  Added crushed potato chips on top and then added grated cheddar.   This was superb!  I made this dish twice previously and thought it was very bland so made some changes.  Actually my recipe  was more like a fancy mac & cheese with tuna added.   Anyway hubby liked it any way I made it but I liked this "kicked up a notch" recipe.

text:
This ended up being a lot better than I expected, considering the ill-equipped kitchen I made it in. I used one can of nacho cheese soup and one of cream of mushroom, then topped it with crushed white cheddar Cheezits instead of potato chips. Also, not sure how much this helped, but after reading the reviews about it being dry, I did not drain the tuna before adding it and stirred in a little water as well. Didn't dry out while baking. My husband, our friend, and I pretty well destroyed that casserole for dinner. It was pretty quick and easy to throw together (or would have been if I had been in my own kitchen), so that combined with it tasting pretty darn good too really makes it a 5-star in my book. Thank you for sharing your recipe!

I saw other reviews about it being dry and decided to mesh this recipe with another.  I used 8 oz elbow macaroni, only one can of soup, about 2-3 oz cream cheese and 1 cup of condensed milk which I whisked into melted butter/flour. I added the grated cheddar to the hot milk.  I added broiled cauliflower and steamed broccoli to make it healthier.  I couldn't believe how much I liked this!  I always thought tuna casserole was a disgusting thing thrown together by people who didn't know how to cook.  Guess I really went way off recipe here, though.

text:
I've made this recipe many times. At first, I followed the recipe exactly (minus the peas and onion, my bf doesn't like them). It was good (probably would have been better with onion, imo!). 

However,  I've changed things around my family's preference. I added corn instead of peas. I used 3 cans of soup (cream of celery, mushroom and chicken). I added spices (garlic, onion and seasoning salt) and used more tuna. I do 16 oz of noodles with 4 cans of tuna and it comes out moist, creamy and  tunalious. Also, I've tried all kinds of shredded cheeses in this and I think that sharp cheese works best -- adds the most flavor. 

Before I tried this recipe, I had never had tuna casserole, now I have it every other week so thanks for sharing this recipe with me!

I added about a cup of cream.   I did not mix cheese in.  I just added it to the top.  I crumbled ritz crackers with a tiny bit of butter and put it on top of the casserole and covered with cheese.  Cover the casserole loosely when cooking.  I added salt, pepper and garlic powder.  I also used fresh mushrooms and cooked the mushrooms and onions before I put them into the mixture.  All in all was very good.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Our family thought this was great! However, can't say I completely stuck to the recipe here. Word of advice, saute onions some first or they will be crunchy.  I had used a little under 1/4 cup of white onions, so it was fine & not too strong of flavor. Didn't have 2 cans of mush soup so used a cup of sour cream instead of another can.  Also, used 1/4 c up half & half, and 1/4 cup of almond milk poured over the ingredients once they were in the dish to keep it from being too dry.  I also used broccoli (steamed 10 minuted first, then diced up) since I didn't have peas.  Another change with cheese was to use about 1/4 c up English cheddar since I had some, and the kind of cheddar we used was sharp.  Added a little bit of parmesan (powder kind) to the bread crumbs (didn't have potato chips), & about 1 tablespoon & a half of melted butter to mixed the bread crumbs so they got a nice crunch & golden brown color to them.  Also sprinkled some pepper and cayenne to the mix before putting it in the oven.

I've never made a tuna casserole before.  Made tonight, and with the help of some reviews, I decided to make some adjustments.  I added 1/2 can of milk to the mixture and instead of canned mushrooms, I used 2 Roma/Italian  Tomatoes (diced) to add more colour.
I didn't measure out the amount of cheese or chips for the top. Also, I went with rippled chips to enhance the crunch. Baked in a casserole dish, for 15 minutes. Next time I will leave it in for a couple more minutes.
Okay, getting to the point, my eleven year old son and I loved it and now this will become a Mom favourite for him!!  Thank you :)

userID:
1088190
Display Name:
Dominic Brunetti
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
29
favoritesCount:
79
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2782990.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought it was a good base, but kind of bland.  What I did:

1)  Once the noodles are drained, put in large bowl and add about 1Tb salted butter and mix them up before adding the rest...
2)  Use one each of the following 10.5oz condensed soups: Cream of Mushroom, Cream of Celery, and Broccoli Cheddar
3)  I omit mushrooms (personal taste) and use 1 1/2 cups of frozen peas
4)  Add 1/3 of a can of milk to each soup can to coax out the stuff that sticks behind and pour into bowl (so add 1 cup of milk)
5)  Add 1 cup FINELY shredded cheddar
6)  Add 3 PACKETS (the stuff not in a can - 5oz each) of tuna in water and mix well in bowl.  Pour into large casserole dish (mine is 13"x9")
7)  Use a about 1/2 can of reduced fat Pringles (regular flavor) and finely crumble all over the top
8)  Top with the leftover cup of cheese and bake for about 30 minutes until the cheese is melted.  I let it sit in the warm (but off) oven until it's time to serve.  My family loves this dish!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I looked for a tuna casserole recipe my departed mother made for us growing up.  This was the one I found that was the closest to her recipe.  I read the reviews and incorporated several of the suggestions.  I omitted the peas as I don't recall them in her casserole.  I sauteed fresh mushrooms and the onion, added black pepper and chopped Spanish green olives with pimento,  the juices from the canned tuna and perhaps 1/4 cup of Sauvignon Blanc.  Baked at 350 with the pot covered.  Moist, flavorful, cheesy, no complaints.  AWESOME.  Will make again. And Again.

userID:
10739387
Display Name:
Jessica
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Beware! I am admitting to changing this recipe based on reviews and watching the video which show a somewhat dry looking dish. 

I pretty much used this recipe as a base and made the following adjustments:
*Dill and tuna work well together so I decided to put salt and dill in my pasta water so the flavor enhanced the noodles a bit.
*used all 12 oz of egg noodles
*didn't realize I was out of onions (which NEVER happens) so I sprinkled the cooked noodles with onion powder quite liberally after draining them. Also added a small amount of butter and salt and pepper at that time.
*Used a family size can of mushroom soup and small can of cheddar cheese soup.
*omitted mushrooms...the mushroom soup had enough
*put most of the shredded cheddar cheese in the mixture and left just enough to sprinkle on top.
*added a dash of smoked paprika because I had some.
*my mixture was thick so I added some milk to loosen it up a bit.
*yes, I kept the peas and potato chips
*Baked at 350 for 30 minutes or more...until bubbly.
My family ages 37 to 14 months DEVOURED this! Not the healthiest dish, but delicious and we have leftovers for tomorrow. Will make it again this winter. Definitely a hearty winter dish.  Very rich and creamy!! We had it with a green side salad.

text:
I took the reviews that said it was dry in consideration and the reviews of peoples revisions. I liked the revision of some people that said they added sour cream, milk and butter. I also used someones revision of using the tuna juices for more flavor and extra moisture. I added about half a cup of sour cream, 1/3 cup of milk and a tbs of butter. My husband and i dont like onions so i put a little over a  tsp of onion powder. My husband doesn't like mushrooms and hates cream of mushroom soup, i did not add the mushrooms but still used cream of mushroom soup. I used a blend of cheddar and Monterey jack to mix in the casserole and topped it with mozzarella because that was the only cheese we had.I forgot to buy pees so those didn't make it in there either. I also added about a tsp of celery salt, a few dashes of salt and pepper. I baked it at 350 for 25 mins. My husband loved it, and i also thought it was better than my dads recipe (thats saying alot because he is the best homecook i know, but latly i have been taking his recipes and making them much better)

As written this is a good base recipe, but pretty bland. It needs some work. I sauteed some celery and the onion beforehand to ensure they cook down, i used fresh mushrooms instead of canned and i used 3 cans of soup, about 1/2 soup can of milk and 1/4 c or so of sour cream, a pinch of garlic powder and a pinch of cayenne and it was excellent. Add whatever seasonings you like otherwise it will be incredibly bland.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was amazing but I made major changes: I halved the recipe (except for the cheese: 1 cup mixed in & 1 cup on top). I sautéed the onion, peas and some minced garlic in 3/4 cup butter and used the melted butter in the recipe. I added a few heaping spoonfuls of miracle whip and a small squirt of mustard. Instead of tuna I used a can of chicken in buffalo sauce (didn't drain sauce). I added the rest of the ingredients except for the can of mushrooms and chip crumbs. I baked it at 350° for 20 minutes. Then I broiled the cheese on top until crispy and light brown. The buffalo flavor was subtle but there was definitely a zip of flavor that was delicious. The casserole was very rich and creamy and I'm definitely making it again using these changes!!

text:
I love this dish! I did change it up a bit though. I used 2 cans of condensed cream of mushroom soup with roasted garlic flavor. Also instead of green peas, I chopped up a half fresh Jalapeno to add some spice. For the cheese, I did one cup cheddar and one cup mozzarella to make it a little healthier. I did not use chips. This came out amazing! Next time, I am going to use the whole jalapeno and add cherry tomatoes and then also sauté the onions in olive oil beforehand.

text:
Great! Used 36.5 ounces total (1-26 oz can and 1- 10.5 oz can) of Cream of Mushroom soup.  Omitted the extra can of mushrooms. Reduced noodles to about 8 ounces (half of a 16 oz bag). Added 1 cup of milk and 1/3 cup sour cream plus 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp black pepper, 1 dash each cayenne pepper and paprika.  Mixture was therefore soupy before baking but after baking the casserole was perfectly moist.

text:
Like everyone else, I needed a base recipe upon which to make my own changes. I add 1 C of sour cream, corn and black beans (along with peas), omit the onion and mushrooms (we don't like them) and add garlic and onion powder, cayenne, Johnny's and a diced jalapeno (we like it spicy!). Then for the top, I crumble Tims Jalapeno chips. YUMMYYYYY!!!!! I never liked tuna casserole in the past but this is one of my all time favorites now!

text:
This casserole was good but I prefer something creamier so I usually make a sauce instead of canned soup - which I tried out as I was pressed for time! I sauteed the onions in a pan first before adding to the dish which was a nice subtle sweetness, and bypassed the crunchiness. I also used panko crumbs instead of chips which was still a nice topping and used cheese only in the mix and not on top. All in all, really quick and tasty.

country:
None
text:
My first time making and trying tuna casserole - it was very good!  My husband liked it as well.  I added more onion and sauteed till almost caramelized before adding to the mixture. I also used fresh mushrooms vs canned and left out the peas since neither my husband nor I like them.  Per other's suggestions I added at least a cup of sour cream and also added a dash of Worcestershire Sauce and Thyme.  I combined everything in a warm pan before placing in the baking dish.  I used French's onions instead of chips, which were really good but imagine the chips would give it a nice crunch as well. Make sure and wait and put French's Onions on top at very end of baking, I put on for the full 15 - 20 min and they got a little too brown.  I will definitely start making this on a regular basis!

text:
I've made this recipe a few times and after preparing it exactly as the recipe instructed the first time have made 4 changes.   The first is I cook the onions for about 3-4 minutes before adding them to the casserole, the second I add 3 cans of cream of mushroom soup, the third is I use spicy bread crumbs instead of the potato chips, and the fourth is I don't drain the tuna to add a little liquid to the casserole.  My sixteen year old hates any kind of fish but will actually eat this.  I would have given this recipe five stars but if prepared exactly as instructed its far too dry and too salty with the potato chips.

text:
I made this recently and it was great. I've never made or eaten tuna casserole before and I loved it. I didn't have chips, so I didn't use any. Also, I used a family size can of cream of mushroom soup (I think it was 25 oz.) so it would be creamy. I took the suggestion to add pimento and kept the peas, it was nice and colorful, and tasted great. Needed some salt and pepper, though. I didn't really measure the cheese, I estimated and probably used slightly more than the recipe and mixed it all in rather than on top. Also, the noodles were 16 oz. I think. I used the whole package and put it in a 9x13 pan. I cooked it on 350 but the frozen peas still seemed a little crunchy. That might have been my imagination, though. All in all, great recipe!

I would suggest sautéing the onion, we used a white onion but really any onion sautéed would be good. I followed the recipe pretty much to the letter. I did add extra cheese and would either add sour cream or milk next time. I did the cheese on top first and then topped with thin potato chips which browned nicely. I was craving my moms tuna casserole and since she has been gone 28 years and I've only attempted this recipe once before this was spot on! Oh yes and I also used frozen peas and doubled them as well! For sure will rewrite this for my kids to have!

text:
I made this recipe tonight with some modifications.  With the small changes, it was fantastic!  First I used bow tie pasta and added about 2 T. of chopped garlic to the water toward the end of the cooking time.  I drained the pasta and garlic over the top of 2 cups of peas in a strainer.  I added one soup can of milk to the base mixture and put the cheese in to blend.  I then topped it with French's fried onions and some garlic salt with about a cup of shredded cheddar cheese.  I used a lasagna pan and lightly covered the pan with some foil during the cooking time.  It was a hit!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Lovely recipe. Made the following modifications to use what I already have on hand and to limit the saturated fat:
1. Organic Penne Ziti instead of egg noodles.
2. Fresh mushrooms and 1/2 sweet onion.  Lightly sautéed in 1/4 tbsp. butter for taste before mixing in with the pasta.
3. 1 can Recipe Starters creamy mushroom and 1/2 can three-cheese.
4. Skipped the peas.
5. Added a healthy splash of Worcestershire sauce and a pinch of onion powder and garlic salt.
6. Panko crumbs instead of bread crumbs.
7. Baked in non-stick sauté pan (the type with a coarse bottom for searing).  The bottom is more evenly done and doesn't stick.
It is very creamy and moist.  Wow!

text:
This is a very good recipe, however, first of all, my husband doesn't like peas, so I completely omitted them.  Also, instead of 2 cans of cream of mushroom soup, I only used one, and then added a 8 oz. of sour cream in place of the 2nd can of soup. Even young children will enjoy the crispy potato chip crumbs.

text:
I have made this many times and here is my best way. I mix this recipe with the from scratch recipe so I use 1 can of whatever condensed soup I want that night and mix that with a celery, onion, butter and flour type gravy soup, I also use total about 2 1/4  cups of milk and half cup sour cream for an entire bag if noodles I put the final half cup milk in half way thru cooking. I use swiss cheese on my first layer as we are fans, we like spicy so on the adult portions we top with buffalo sauce, and finally we smoother it over honey cornbread for a heartier meal! Hope this helps! Enjoy

text:
good bones, but I had to tweek it which is why I only rated it 3 stars.  The way it's written it would have been too dry for my taste.  I upped the sauce content to 1 can cream of mushroom, 1 can cream of celery and 1 small container of sour cream and also added about 1 cup of milk.  I also don't like onions raw so I cooked-sautee'd them with some minced garlic, prior to adding them in. I also don't like mushrooms so I omitted them.  I also added Salt and Pepper to taste.   like I said this recipe was a great starting point for me to customize for my taste.  I thought this recipe would be really good with kielbasa or ham instead of tuna, as well!

This is a very good easy tuna casserole, but I'm giving it 3 stars because I think the measurements were way off and the prep time was more than stated.  Too many noodles!  I used 2-1/2 c. I will make again with those adjustments.

userID:
4909362
Display Name:
dpartn
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe.   It does require a bit of modification in my opinion.   The biggest element about this recipe as written is that it lacks moisture.  I pretty much make a double batch and the first time I made it I could see when mixing it all together that it was going to need something to make it moist.  I just added a couple cups of milk.  Even when I added milk the first time out it still came out a little dry.   Don't be afraid to use milk (or water) when using condensed soup as the binding agent. 
Also, mix it very very well.  I used a mixture of cheddar and italian mixed cheese.  Cheese is a preference thing.  there is no wrong cheese to use (within logical reason) so use it as it is or add your favorite kind.

Also, if you use a convection oven as I do, you need to convert the temp.  I run my over for this recipe at 375 and add some time to cook it through.  the first time I forgot to convert and 425 at 15 minutes had the potato chips and cheddar dark dark brown. so I converted to 375 for about 30 minutes.

Overall this is a great recipe.  Just add some milk and make sure you mix thoroughly.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-08-07T13:09:13.093
helpfulCount:

text:
I like many others am not a tuna casserole fan. Not until this recipe. I took advice from some of the other people who responded and sauteed the onion with garlic in butter , then substituted one of the cans of soup with cream of celery. Used canned mushrooms and added about 3/4 C of sour cream and the same amount of milk.  I didn't have potato chips so instead I crumbled "Club" crackers on top and this was absolutely delicious. I reduced the temp to 375 because I omitted the peas and pre-cooked the onion. It was moist and the crackers gave it the right amount of crunch. Yummmm

text:
It was ok -- my friend and I made it as the recipe exactly as instructed and it was as most people said... very dry. I also found it to be rather bland. I would make it again but make the following changes: 
- I would add milk + sour cream.. I think it's really weird that the recipe doesn't call for this to begin with, I'm no culinary genius but whenever I use canned soup for anything I always make sure to add milk.
- I would not use as much onion. It was overwhelming. 
- It needed spices so much. If you follow the directions exactly it is sooo bland. The next day the flavors blended together more but.. still.. Personally I would try adding tarragon next time since I know tuna and tarragon go well together.

text:
I liked it, was hoping to love it, but I'm rating a 3 be-c noone else in my family liked it. Unfortunately my husband came in to the meal with a bias against tuna with pasta and I think that prevented him from trying to try and ejoy it. He loves my tuna salads on crackers or bread, but doesn't like any tuna pasta salads or hamburger helper type meals much. What he most liked was my cruncy topping made of a mix of potato chips, grated cheddar and french's fried onion bits. Unfortunately, I have more than half left with noone else who will want to eat leftovers, they could barely eat firsts! So i guess y'all know what I'll be eating again soon. 

I too changed mine up a bit and still it wasn't all that. Here is what I did, since we don't like mushrooms I only used 1 can cream of mush and 1 can cream of celery. I added about 1 1/2 cups peas and 1 cup corn be-c we love vegetables (okay, except mushrooms). I also added about 2 half cans of milk (1 from each of my differing cans) and added garlic salt and fresh ground pepper. Mine came out nice and creamy and I only added the cheesy crunch topping in the last 5 to 7 mins. of baking time so they would stay crunchy. Looked good but unfortunately not a winner and one I will not be making again. Thanks anyway as it was an easy meal to prepare.

text:
5 stars for a great base recipe. I modified it with what I had on hand and it turned out amazing. I sauteed the onions with garlic in a tad bit of butter first. I used 1 lb box of Barilla elbows and added about a cup each of frozen peas and corn. I used 2 cans of 25% less sodium cream of mush soup, and just added garlic powder, black pepper, chili powder and seasoned salt to taste and one 12 oz can of albacore tuna, juices and all since I had no milk to add. I put a small amount of cubed pepper jack cheese, along with shredded colby jack mixed with everything. On top I layered a thin layer of colby jack, a few strips of pepper jack, then thin layer of bread crumbs followed by another thin layer of shredded colby jack. I baked it same as the recipe called for. Everything was excellent.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This my first review. Husband loved it (calling it almost a 10, very very picky kids (2,4 and 7) were willing to eat the chips (duh) and pasta plain with some butter. I tried to make it as close to wheat free as I could. Here are the revisions I made that worked for us. I only had one can of cream of mushroom (which was 98% fat free) so basically I halved the recipe. I deleted the peas, used corn penne pasta (from Trader Joes) that is gluten free, added 1/2 cup milk per other suggestions, added 1/2 can of mild green chiles and used crunched up Maui Onion Kettle Chips (also wheat/gluten free) on the top after I took the casserole out of the oven. We are not a gluten/wheat free family but considering going that route for better health. Also, if you are wheat free, please note that the cream of mushroom soup does have some wheat in it. I will look for a substitute for it. This is an easy recipe for sure!

country:
None
text:
Well I didn't have everything to make this tuna noodle casserole but it was still the bomb. I didn't have shredded cheese but I did have packages of sliced colby and Pepper Jack cheese, I had mixed veggies instead of peas and french fried onions instead of potato chips. So with all this in mind I made up the casserole as directed above replacing peas with mixed veggies. Since I had sliced cheese I did one lay of everything mixed together then did a layer alternating the two kinds of cheese then poured the rest of the mixture and layered alternating the different kinds of cheese. Then I ran the French Fried Onions thru the processor to make crumbles then baked. Oh my goodness!! The flavor was absolutely delish and there was a kick to my Tuna Noodle Casserole.

Very good - the kids liked it, and it was super easy and fast. I used shells since I didn't have egg noodles, and buttered saltines since I didn't have potato chips. I didn't have peas or mushrooms - which was fine since my kids don't like either. I used a 9x13, cooked at 350 for 15-20 minutes. Very flexible recipe. It's a keeper!

text:
This was a good recipe and very easy to make. I took some advice from others and sauteed the onions first before adding it to the casserole to bake so it wouldn't be undercooked, I seasoned the mix with some salt and garlic salt so it wouldn't be plain, I added 1 can milk and about half cup of sour cream so it wouldn't be dry. I used panko bread crumbs.  I also baked this in a 9X12 disposable aluminum tray and it cooked with no troubles. Would make again.

region:

country:
None
text:
Just tried this recipe tonight.  I love the recipes on this site that help you have a foundation to begin with and then you can make it your own.  I like seasoning so I added seasoning: garlic powder, black pepper, ground coriander and small dose of cayenne pepper. I never, ever add as much onion as anyone suggests so I only added finely chopped, maybe the 1/4 cup. I also added 1/2 cup milk and 1/2 cup plain yogurt to combat the dryness that other reported.  Very good and tasty.  Four stars since I had to add moisture.

country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe, but I modified it as well. Added a cup of sour cream and 1/3 cup of milk. Also used fresh finely sliced mushrooms (about 1 cup), and a whole minced onion. Added garlic to the onion and sauteed it in olive oil before adding it to the mixture. I also added about 3/4 of a teaspoon of Cayenne pepper, and 1/2 a teaspoon celery salt. Salt and black pepper to taste. Didn't use the potato chips as stated, not necessary.

I did the modifications the second time around of making this, and my husband LOVES this recipe with the Cayenne pepper. It gives it a great kick.

I had nothing thawed and had to turn to the pantry tonight. My husband hates fish in all forms, so I thought I'd pull a fast one on him with this recipe. I added about 1/2 cup of milk, sauteed mushrooms and onions before adding to the mix, added a good shake of cayenne, added frozen mixed veggies instead of just peas, and used some nice, thick spaetzle in place of the egg noodles. It was so good my husband went back for thirds before he realized he was eating fish. Definitely a winner and a great pantry recipe.

Display Name:
MrsJPS

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/75060.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a lovely casserole with some modifications (which is why I dropped a star).  I took reviewer suggestions and upped the sauce by adding an extra can of soup (this one cream of chicken) and a full can of milk -- it made it the PERFECT creaminess, so I wouldn't dream of making it with any less.  I left out the peas and mushrooms since both of them are not my favorite, and I used extra onion but sauteed them first so they wouldn't overpower the dish, which they didn't.  Made it in a 2-qt casserole as suggested by others, and I waited until the very end before sprinkling the cheese on top of the chips -- just added it when the casserole was done and put it back in just long enough to let it melt, so the cheese didn't get crispy at all.  Comfort food at it's best!

Excellent - very tasty and simple and exactly what I was looking for.  Did add 1/2 cup of milk to recipe to make it a bit more juicy. text:
Great base recipe that you can modify to fit your tastes! I did end up adding about 4 oz. sour cream so this didn't end up dry. Topped with parmesan cheese instead of crushed chips because I didn't want the topping to be to greasy. Also, I shredded my own cheese -this is the way to go! Shredding your own is cheaper and the cheese doesn't have that nasty powder stuff on it t keep from sticking. This recipe is a keeper and I will make again.

text:
Made this for I and my sweetie, she loves tuna... And this was a hit for us.. I did take the advice of other reviews and added and subtracted from the original. I went with the two cans of mushroom soup, and a can of cheddar cheese soup, about 1/4 milk and lil bit of mayonnaise about 1/4 cup or less. I took out the onions and used both croutons and some left over chips. The croutons definitely give it a bit more crunch, Next time I make this I will try waiting until the dish is almost done baking before adding the chips. I have found this one recipe that be adjusted to ones taste, and I don't think you can go wrong with it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was good, just not what Im used to. My mother has her own recipe that she made while I was growing up and it had a totally different taste.  Here is my Moms recipe that I preferred over this one:  1 large bag of egg noodles 2 cans of Cream of Mushroom 2 cans of tuna 1/2 & 1/2  Milk Mrs. Dash Salt and pepper Garlic powder Potato chips  Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Boil noodles for 8-10 minutes until al dente. Drain, and put cooked noodles back into stock pot.   Add 1/2 & 1/2, fill stock pot half way up the noodles. Add milk the rest of the way until just about covering the noodles.   Add seasoning and mix well (you can be generous with the seasoning). Cover stock pot and uncover when half way done to get the top of the noodles crispy. Bake for 1 and 1/2 hours.  When done, let it sit for 5 minutes before serving. Add crushed potato chips to the top of your individual serving.

text:
Although I wasn't too sure about the tuna, with a few modifications I made, as I didn't have some of the ingredients, the casserole came out really good!!! I added milk as otherwise it would have came out too dry. I also added 2 tbsp of sour cream, 1/4 tspn of cayenne pepper, 1/2 cup of canned whole kernel corn, and the onion that the recipe called for, I sauteed it prior to adding it to the mix and also added 2 tbsp of butter. I fried thin sliced potatoes as I didn't have any potato chips, and also added some Southwestern style browned hash browns on top, before adding the second cup of cheddar cheese. In the future, I would add some salt and pepper and see how it comes out.

text:
I'm not a big fan of tuna casserole and made this per my family's request.  We all loved it - even me.  I tweaked just a little: added less onion (for kids) but then used onion powder and garlic powder, used Italian bread crumbs instead of potato chips, and added a splash of milk (due to some reviews saying it was dry).  It came out great.

My family is quite skeptical about tuna casseroles, but this one put their fears to rest. The combination of the soups and cheese made a lovely casserole that didn't have that overwhelming tuna flavor that so often comes with a tuna casserole. Make the recipe just as is...it works!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is almost the same as the recipe that my family has been using for years, and it's a good simple staple. My mother always used cream of mushroom soup, but I found that substituting cream of chicken for half (or even all) of it adds some good flavor; 1 large can of cream of chicken and 1 small can of cream of mushroom is my favorite combo, and adds a little extra moisture. Egg noodles are good, but other kinds of pasta work too (garden rotini is nice). I like crumbled sour cream and onion Pringles on mine (there's something about the texture that I like, even though I don't normally like Pringles), but my husband prefers Italian bread crumbs. Both are good. I've never included onion and cheese but I think I will next time because it sounds like a good addition.

Quite good. Very easy to pull together. My only change to the recipe was that I added frozen peas with carrots, not just peas. I will say that this recipe makes a lot of food, much more than what I would call 6 servings. I think if you cut it in half it would easily feed a family of four. text:
I used one can of cream of mushroom and one cream of celery. I added milk, as it was looking dry, like others suggested. I used good tuna, good frozen peas, Lay's potatoe chips. No onions or mushrooms, but added onion powder and garlic salt.  I hated it. It was very fishy, my husband liked it, but thought the cheese was too hard on top (I didnt burn it). Our company added more cheese while eating it and salt and pepper. I guess I am too snobby for Tuna Casserole, my mother and grandmother never made it, now I see why...

text:
This recipe was totally bland!  I did add an extra 1/2 c. of milk to the original recipe and baked for 15 minutes, so the casserole was nice and moist.  But to make this recipe truly wonderful, you MUST: saute those onions and mushrooms first, throw in a clove or two of garlic, and add at least 1/2 tsp of salt and pepper.  I couldn't even taste the tuna in this casserole, so I would add another can of tuna as well!  Casserole out of a box has more flavor than this recipe as is.

text:
I so appreciate comments others have made.  This recipe - as a base - is a very good one.  I created a hybrid from comments others have made and created a delicious casserole last evening.  I used an 18 oz bag of noodles, two cans of creme of mushroom soup, one can of cheddar cheese soup and a half cup milk.  Mixed with 3 - 6 oz cans of tuna, peas, shredded cheese, etc.  I topped it with crumled potato chips and a little of the shredded cheese and baked for 40 minutes because I used a deeper casserole dish.  All this to say that I cannot wait to have the leftovers today. It was a great base recipe and i hope to try the canned asparagus spears on another winter weekend in this hearty, satisfying dish.

text:
VERY GOOD, except I agree with other reviewers, that the onion needs to be pre-cooked or it isn't done(soft). I liked that a 9 x 13 was used at a higher temp, so it didn't take as long as some casseroles. But be careful not to over-bake, it dries out easily/ fast!. Just bake until heated through. I opted to use frozen mixed veggies instead of just peas(just pre cooked a little in the noodle pan with a little butter AND I added a little milk to make it creamier. I didn't have the chips on hand, so I just crushed some "buttery" (Ritz type)crackers with the cheese to top. Will make again,  with my changes.

text:
I thought this was pretty good! I took the advice of other users and added the can of milk. It didn't come out dry at all. I also added salt, pepper, and garlic salt to taste. If I didn't add the milk and seasoning, I think this would've been bland. I also added an extra can of tuna. Next time I might even use 4 cans. So if you're planning to try this recipe out, be sure to add your own seasoning and some milk or else it won't turn out good!!

I made some changes to mine. I omitted the onion, and put all the cheese in the mix *that was an accident*, I used a family sized mushroom soup instead of the two cans and used fresh mushrooms instead of canned. For the potato chips I used cheddar sour cream *mainly because those were the only ones opened when I made the recipe* Realizing I used all the cheese in the mixture I grabbed my mexican cheese blend from the fridge *bought for enchilidas the next night* It gave it a bit of a kick, really yummy!

text:
Very good.  Flavors were great.  Not cooking the onion before putting in the casserole leaves it some 'bite'.  Used fine bread crumbs instead of potato chips and was delicious.  Didn't have any mushrooms to add, but didn't miss them at all; the soup gives more than enough flavor.  However, it wasn't quite as good as a leftover.

text:
I made some easy variations to the recipe. I doulbed the mushrooms and added about 2/3 cup of reduced fat sour cream. It made it very creamy. It's the best tuna casserole I've ever made and the family loves it!
